ARTICLE I:  IN GENERAL



§ 2-1  ELECTIONS GENERALLY.



   The city shall conduct its own municipal elections with a municipal
board of elections which is regulated by G.S. Chapter 163, and the elections
shall be conducted as regulated by the election laws contained in G.S.
Chapter 163.



§ 2-2  NONPARTISAN PRIMARIES AND ELECTIONS.



   The City Council hereby adopts and reaffirms the nonpartisan plurality
election method (type no. 1) of determining election results for municipal
elections (G.S. § 163-294).



(Res. passed 1-4-1972; Ord. 93-006, passed 5-11-1993)



Charter reference:



   Election of Councilmen; term; filing as candidates for reelection, see
§ 6.5



   Election of Mayor, see § 6.2



Statutory reference:



   Authorization, see G.S. § 160A-101(7)(b)



   Definition, see G.S. § 163-292



§ 2-3  REGISTRATION METHOD.



   A full-time registration office shall be made available for
registration of voters pursuant to method D of G.S. § 163-288.



ARTICLE II:  MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL



Division 1:  Generally



§ 2-26  COMPOSITION OF GOVERNING BODY.



   The governing body of the city shall consist of a Council of five
members, who shall be elected in accordance with the provisions of state law.



(1972 Code, § 2-6)



Charter reference:



   Composition of City Council; designation and duties of Mayor, see § 4.1



§ 2-27  COMPENSATION AND REIMBURSEMENT FOR EXPENSES.



   The compensation for the Mayor and members of the Council shall be as
follows and/or to be determined by Council from time to time:



   (A)   Mayor, $6,000 per year, payable semi-annually; and



   (B)   Each member of the Council, $4,000 per year, payable
semi-annually.



   (C)   The Mayor and each member of the Council is entitled to
reimbursement for actual expenses incurred in the course of performing his or
her official duties at rates not in excess of those allowed to other city
officials and employees, or to a fixed allowance, the amount of which shall
be established by the Council, for travel and other personal expenses of
office, provided that any fixed allowance so established during a term of
office shall not be increased during such term of office.



(1972 Code, § 2-7)  (Ord. 2016-07, passed 5-24-2016)



Division 2:  City Council



§ 2-41  POWERS; ENACTING ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS AND THE LIKE.



   The Council shall have power to enact amendments to this Code, the
Charter, ordinances, resolutions or bylaws, for the better government of the
city, not inconsistent with the Charter or laws of the land.



(1972 Code, § 2-8)



Charter reference:



   Exercise of city powers, see § 4.9



Statutory reference:



   General ordinance-making power, see G.S. § 160A-174



§ 2-42  POWERS; CONSOLIDATION OF OFFICES.



   The Council may in its discretion consolidate any two or more offices
and assign the duties of both offices to one or more persons.



(1972 Code, § 2-9)



Charter reference:



   Consolidation of functions of certain offices, see § 7.6



§ 2-43  MEETINGS; REGULAR.



   There shall be regular meetings of the Council held at City Hall or at
another place as may be designated on the second Tuesday of each month at
7:00 p.m. unless otherwise specified, in which case proper notice shall be
given and each member of the Council shall be notified pursuant to state
statute.



(1972 Code, § 2-10)  (Ord. passed 6-14-1994)



Charter reference:



   Meetings of City Council, see § 4.7



Statutory reference:



   Council meetings, see G.S. §§ 160A-68, 160A-71



§ 2-44  MEETINGS; SPECIAL.



   (A)   The Mayor, the Mayor Pro Tempore or any two members of the
Council may at any time call a special Council meeting by signing a written
notice stating the time and place of the meeting and the subjects to be
considered.



   (B)   The notice shall be delivered to the Mayor and each Council
member or left at his or her usual dwelling place at least six hours before
the meeting.



(1972 Code, § 2-11)



Statutory reference:



   Council meetings, see G.S. § 160A-71



   Public notice of official meetings, see G.S.§  143-318.12



§ 2-45  MEETINGS; ADJOURNED.



   If a quorum fails to attend any regular or special meeting of the
Council or if for any reason the meeting fails to complete the transaction of
the business before the meeting, the meeting may be adjourned to any date
prior to the next regular meeting agreed upon by a majority of the members
present.



(1972 Code, § 2-12)



§ 2-46  MAYOR PRESIDES OVER MEETINGS.



   The Mayor, when present, shall preside at all meetings of the Council.
In case of the absence of the Mayor, the Mayor Pro Tempore shall preside.



(1972 Code, § 2-13)



Charter reference:



   Composition of City Council; designation and duties of Mayor, see § 4.1



§ 2-47  RULES OF PROCEDURE; QUORUM.



   (A)   Except as otherwise provided, the procedure of the Council
shall be governed by Robert’s Rules of Order.



   (B)   A majority of the total members of the Council shall
constitute a quorum.



(1972 Code, § 2-14)



Charter reference:



   Quorum; voting, see § 4.8



   Rules and journal of proceedings, see § 4.5



§ 2-48  ORDER OF BUSINESS.



   (A)   The order of business at all regular Council meetings shall be
as set forth in the published agenda.



   (B)   If the Council directs any matter to be the special business
of a future meeting, the same shall have precedence over all other business
at the meeting.



   (C)   No proposition shall be entertained by the Mayor until it has
been seconded, and every proposition, when required by the Mayor or any
member of the Council, shall be reduced to writing.



(1972 Code, § 2-15)



Charter reference:



   Order of business, see § 4.5



§ 2-49  ELECTIONS BY BALLOT.



   All elections by the Council shall be by ballot, if required by any two
members present.



(1972 Code, § 2-16)



§ 2-50  RESIGNATION OF MEMBER.



   Resignation of any Council member shall be in writing, and the
resignation shall lie on the table until the next regular meeting unless
considered by unanimous consent.



(1972 Code, § 2-17)



§ 2-51  DISQUALIFICATION OF MEMBER.



   If any member of the Council or the Mayor moves his or her residence
from the city, his or her office shall be declared vacant at once.



(1972 Code, § 2-18)



Division 3:  Mayor



§ 2-61  DUTIES.



   It shall be the duty of the Mayor to:



   (A)   Act as ceremonial head of the city government;



   (B)   Preside over the meetings of the Council;



   (C)   Sign all contracts, ordinances, resolutions, papers or
writings authorized by the city; and



   (D)   Appoint special committees and outline their powers and duties
as he or she deems necessary to properly care for the affairs of the city.



(1972 Code, § 2-19)



Charter reference:



   Mayor generally, see § 4.1



§ 2-62  VOTING IN CASE OF TIE.



   When there is an equal division of the Council upon any question or in
the election of officers, the Mayor may vote to break the tie but shall have
no vote under any other circumstances.



(1972 Code, § 2-20)



ARTICLE III:  CITY OFFICERS



§ 2-86  APPOINTED POSITIONS.



   (A)   The City Council shall appoint the following city officers and
employees:



      (1)   City Manager;



      (2)   City Clerk; and



      (3)   City Attorney.



   (B)   These officers shall serve at the pleasure of the Council.



(1972 Code, § 2-23)



Charter reference:



   Administrative officers, see art. VII



   Police, see art. XIV



Statutory reference:



   General powers of Mayor, see G.S. §§ 160A-67, 160A-69



   Municipal officers, see G.S. §§ 160A-59 et seq.



§ 2-87  CITY MANAGER.



   The City Manager shall be the chief administrator of the city. He or
she shall be responsible to the Council for administering all municipal
affairs placed in his or her charge by it, and shall have the following
powers and duties.



   (A)   He or she shall appoint and suspend or remove all city
officers and employees not elected by the people, and whose appointment or
removal is not otherwise provided for by law, except the City Attorney, in
accordance with general personnel rules, regulations, policies or ordinances
as the Council may adopt.



   (B)   He or she shall direct and supervise the administration of all
departments, offices and agencies of the city, subject to the general
direction and control of the Council, except as otherwise provided by law.



   (C)   He or she shall attend all meetings of the Council and
recommend any measures that he or she deems expedient.



   (D)   He or she shall see that all laws of the state, the City
Charter and the ordinances, resolutions and regulations of the Council are
faithfully executed within the city.



   (E)   He or she shall prepare and submit the annual budget and
capital program to the Council.



   (F)   He or she shall annually submit to the Council and make
available to the public a complete report on the finances and administrative
activities of the city as of the end of the fiscal year.



   (G)   He or she shall make any other reports that the Council may
require concerning the operations of city departments, offices and agencies
subject to his or her direction and control.



   (H)   He or she shall perform any other duties that may be required
or authorized by the Council.



Statutory reference:



   Similar provisions, see G.S. § 160A-148



§ 2-88  CITY CLERK.



   It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to:



   (A)   Act as Clerk to the City Council and, as such, keep a complete
and accurate account of all proceedings of all meetings in a book especially
provided for this purpose by the Council; and



   (B)   Perform other duties as the Council may require.



(1972 Code, § 2-24)



Charter reference:



   Boundary map in City Clerk’s office, see § 2.1



   City Clerk, see § 7.3



   City Finance Director, see § 7.4



Statutory reference:



   Ordinance book, see G.S. § 160A-78



   City Clerk, see G.S. §§ 160A-171, 160A-172



§ 2-89  CITY ATTORNEY.



   It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to:



   (A)   Prosecute and defend suits for and against the city;



   (B)   Advise the Mayor, City Manager, Council or any other officer
of the city in regard to matters connected with the city’s business;



   (C)   Attend meetings of the Council when requested to do so by it;



   (D)   Draw those deeds, contracts, bonds, notes and other legal
papers as may be required for the proper conduct of the city’s business; and



   (E)   Approve all ordinances as to form before their introduction.



(1972 Code, § 2-26)



Charter reference:



   City Attorney, see § 7.2



Statutory reference:



   City Attorney, see G.S. § 160A-173



ARTICLE IV:  BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND DEPARTMENTS



Division 1:  Generally



§ 2-111  ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE CONTROL BOARD.



   The Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, also referred to as the ABC
Board, is hereby established as a body of five members. The Board shall
provide for its own organization and shall provide the City Council with a
written description of duties and responsibilities of the Board. The terms on
this Board shall be for three years.



(Ord. 2011-06, passed 9-13-2011; Ord. 5-2012, passed 6-12-2012)



§ 2-112  CITY HOUSING AUTHORITY.



   The City Housing Authority is hereby established as a body of five
members. The members on this Board shall be appointed by the Mayor, and the
terms shall be for five years. The Board shall provide for its own
organization and shall provide the City Council with a written description of
the duties and responsibilities of the Board.



Division 2:  Planning Board



§ 2-121  CREATED.



   A City Planning Board is hereby created pursuant to G.S. §§ 160A-361
et seq. and in accordance with and as restricted by the other laws of the
state.



(1972 Code, § 2-27)



Charter reference:



   Zoning, see art. XI



Statutory reference:



   Interlocal cooperation, see G.S. §§ 160A-460 et seq.



   Planning and regulation of development, see §§ G.S. 160A-360 et seq.



§ 2-122  COMPOSITION; TERMS; VACANCIES; COMPENSATION.



   (A)   The Planning Board shall consist of four members who are
citizens of the city and shall be appointed by the Council and three members
that are residents of the extraterritorial area appointed subject to the
provisions of G.S. § 160A-362. Two alternate members shall also be appointed.



   (B)   Board members shall be appointed for staggered terms of three
years, with initial appointments being as follows: three members shall hold
an appointment for three years, three members shall hold an appointment for
two years, and one member shall hold an appointment for one year.



   (C)   Vacancies occurring for reasons other than expiration of the
term shall be filled by the Council as they occur for the period of the
unexpired term. Faithful attendance of meetings is considered as a
prerequisite for the maintenance of membership on the Board, and the
unexcused absence of any member of the Board for as many as three consecutive
regularly appointed meetings shall constitute a forfeiture of the appointment
of the member. The Council shall have the right to declare the office of the
member vacant and appoint a successor for the unexpired term.



   (D)   All members of the Planning Board are to have equal rights,
duties and responsibilities.



   (E)   Appointed Planning Board members shall be compensated $50 per
meeting or such other amount as determined by the Council.



(Ord. passed 10-11-1977; Ord. 2016-08, passed 5-26-2016; Ord. passed
12-11-2018)



§ 2-123  SITS AS ZONING BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT.



   The Planning Board shall serve as the Zoning Board of Adjustment.



Editor’s note:



   The zoning ordinance is on file in the office of the City Clerk.



§ 2-124  ORGANIZATION AND OFFICERS; RULES; RECORDS.



   Within 30 days after appointment, the Planning Board shall meet and
elect a Chairperson, a Secretary and those other officers as it may
determine. The term of the Chairperson and other officers shall be for one
year with eligibility for reelection. The Board shall adopt rules for the
transaction of business, and shall keep a complete permanent record of
members’ attendance, of resolutions, notations of its discussions, findings
and recommendations. These records shall be a public record and subject to
the inspection of any citizen of the city at any time during office hours.
The records shall be kept in a permanent minute record book, and shall be
typewritten and approved at the next subsequent regular meeting after
recording.



(1972 Code, § 2-29)



§ 2-125  FUNDING.



   The Planning Board may receive any appropriations that are made by the
Council and any gift, grant or donation from any source, made under any
conditions acceptable to the Board and in accordance with law. The Board may
apply for any funds available from the state or from the federal government,
either by way of gifts, grants or loans. However, no obligation regarding any
financial assistance shall be binding upon the city until it has been fully
approved by the Council.



(1972 Code, § 2-30)



Cross-reference:



   Finance and taxation, see ch. 8



§ 2-126  AUTHORIZED EXPENDITURES.



   The expenditures of the Planning Board, exclusive of the proceeds from
gifts, grants or other receipts made unconditionally to the Board and for
which the city is not in any way responsible, shall be in the amounts
appropriated for those purposes by the Council and no other. No indebtedness
for which the city shall be liable in any manner shall be contracted or
incurred by the Board unless an authorized appropriation is made by the
Council for those purposes or specifically approved by the Council as
authorized by law. The Board may accept gifts or donations of any kind of
property and use the same for any lawful purpose which, in the judgment of
the Board, is consistent with the best interest of the planning program.



(1972 Code, § 2-31)



§ 2-127  POWERS AND DUTIES GENERALLY.



   (A)   The Planning Board shall have all of the power and authority
conferred upon the organization by the laws of the state and the laws of the
United States not inconsistent with the Charter and other laws relating to
the city. Any action of the Board shall be subject to review, acceptance,
rejection or modification by the Council at any time after any
recommendations are recorded and approved.



   (B)   The Planning Board shall act as an advisory agency for the
Council.



(1972 Code, § 2-32)



§ 2-128  STUDIES OF LAND USE, POPULATION AND THE LIKE.



   (A)   The Board shall make a careful study of the present conditions
and probable future development of the city and those environs as it is
authorized or may hereafter be authorized to operate in.



   (B)   The studies may include, but are not limited to:



      (1)   Land use surveys; population studies;



      (2)   Economic base studies;



      (3)   Schools, park and recreation studies;



      (4)   Traffic and parking studies;



      (5)   Urban renewal studies; and



      (6)   Any other study of any nature whatsoever that may be
consistent with better planning for the city.



(1972 Code, § 2-33)



§ 2-129  PLANNING FOR DEVELOPMENT.



   (A)   The Planning Board shall formulate and maintain a
comprehensive plan of the city and its environs for the purpose of achieving
a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the city, which would
promote, in accordance with present or future needs, the safety, morals,
order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare of its citizens;
efficiency and economy in the process of development; convenience of traffic;
safety from fire or other dangers; adequate light and air; healthful and
convenient distribution of population; provision of adequate open spaces;
good civic design and arrangement; wise and efficient expenditure of public
funds; adequate provision for utilities; and for other matters pertaining to
the public interests and requirements.



   (B)   The comprehensive plan should consist of a number of parts
which may include, but are not limited to, the following:



      (1)   A land use plan;



      (2)   A utilities plan;



      (3)   A plan for economic development;



      (4)   A recreation plan;



      (5)   A community school plan;



      (6)   A community facilities plan; and



      (7)   Any other feature that may be considered necessary and
desirable.



(1972 Code, § 2-34)



§ 2-130  COOPERATION WITH REDEVELOPMENT AGENCIES.



   The Planning Board shall cooperate with all redevelopment agencies and
shall review all redevelopment plans within 45 days after the receipt of any
plans submitted to the Board. The Board shall certify to those agencies its
recommendations on the same, either for approval, rejection or modification;
if modifications are recommended, they shall be specified to the proper
authorities.



(1972 Code, § 2-35)



§ 2-131  PREPARATION OF SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS.



   The Planning Board may prepare subdivision regulations governing the
subdivision of land within the city and the environs as it has or hereafter
may have any jurisdiction over, and present the same to the Council for its
consideration and possible adoption.



(1972 Code, § 2-36)



§ 2-132  REVIEW AND RECOMMENDATION TO COUNCIL.



   The Planning Board may review and make recommendations to the Council
on the extent, location and design of all public structures and facilities;
on the acquisition and disposal of public properties; upon the opening,
abandonment, widening, extension, narrowing or other change to streets or
other public ways; and on the construction, extension, expansion or
abandonment of utilities, whether publicly or privately owned. However, any
review and recommendations shall be adopted by the Council only in case it
sees fit to adopt the same, the final approving authority in all cases to
remain with the Council.



(1972 Code, § 2-37)



Division 3:  Auxiliary Police



§ 2-145  AUXILIARY POLICE DIVISION.



   There is hereby established within the City Police Department, as a
division thereof, an Auxiliary Police Division. The Auxiliary Police Division
shall be a volunteer organization, whose members shall serve without
compensation, composed of as many members as may from time to time be
determined by the Chief of Police and approved by the City Manager.



(Ord. passed 11-14-2006)



ARTICLE V:  PURCHASING APPARATUS, SUPPLIES, MATERIALS OR EQUIPMENT



§ 2-160  GRANT OF AUTHORITY.



   Subject to the restrictions and conditions hereinafter provided, when
purchasing, apparatus, supplies, materials or equipment for use by the city,
in addition to that authority as may be provided by law and/or otherwise
delegated by the City Council, the City Manager or his or her designee shall
have the authority to:



   (A)   Prepare, or cause to be prepared, plans and/or specifications
setting forth a complete description of the item(s) to be purchased and the
characteristics, features and/or requirements therefor;



   (B)   Include, where appropriate, in specifications for the item(s)
to be purchased an opportunity for bidders to purchase as trade-in specified
personal property owned by the city;



   (C)   Advertise, or otherwise secure bids, for those item(s), if
required under applicable law;



   (D)   Award contracts for the purchase of item(s) and, where
applicable, award contracts for the purchase of the item(s) and the sale of
trade-in property;



   (E)   Reject bids;



   (F)   Readvertise to receive bids;



   (G)   Waive bid bond or deposit requirements;



   (H)   Waive performance and payment bond requirements; and



   (I)   Execute and deliver the purchase contract(s).



(Ord. passed 2-10-1998)



§ 2-161  REPORT.



   At the first meeting of the City Council following the award of any
contract(s) pursuant to this article, the City Manager or his or her designee
shall submit a report to the City Council summarizing the bids received and
the contract(s) awarded. The report shall be included in the minutes of the
meeting at which it is received.



(Ord. passed 2-10-1998)



§ 2-162  EXTENT OF AUTHORITY.



   Except in cases of sole source purchases pursuant to G.S. § 143-129(f)
and cases of purchases from established contracts pursuant to G.S. §
143-129(g) unless otherwise provided by law, the provisions of this article
shall apply to the purchase of apparatus, supplies, materials or equipment
requiring the estimated expenditure of municipal funds in an amount not to
exceed $30,000 for any one item or group of similar items.



OR



   Except in cases of sole source purchases pursuant to G.S. §
143-129(g), unless otherwise provided by law, the provisions of this article
shall apply to the purchase of all apparatus, supplies, materials or
equipment required for use by the city.



(Ord. passed 2-10-1998)



§ 2-163  NO LIMITATION OF OTHER AUTHORITY.



   The provisions of this article are not intended to limit, restrict or
revoke, in any manner, authority otherwise granted and/or delegated to the
City Manager or his or her designee by statute, law or action of the City
Council.



(Ord. passed 2-10-1998)



§ 2-164  APPROPRIATION REQUIRED.



   No purchase shall be made by the City Manager or his or her designee
under authority of this article unless an appropriation for that purpose has
been authorized in the annual budget, or by supplemental appropriation or
budget appropriation amendment duly adopted by the City Council.



(Ord. passed 2-10-1998)



§ 2-165  APPLICATION OF GENERAL STATUTES.



   In acting pursuant to the authority delegated by this article, the City
Manager or his or her designee shall comply with the requirements of G.S.
Chapter 143, Article 8, as from time to time amended, modified, supplemented,
revised or superseded, to the same extent as would have otherwise applied to
the City Council.



(Ord. passed 2-10-1998)



§ 2-166  AUTHORITY.



   This article is enacted pursuant to the provisions of G.S. §
143-129(a).



(Ord. passed 2-10-1998)



ARTICLE VI:  SECURITY SURVEILLANCE POLICY



§ 2-180  SECURITY SURVEILLANCE POLICY.



   (A)   Purpose. It is the policy of the city to place security
cameras on its property where necessary and appropriate to aid in protecting
public safety and as a deterrent to crime. All video monitoring must be
conducted in accordance with applicable laws and regulations, and in a manner
that balances the city’s duty to promote a safe environment with the
privacy rights held by city staff, employees, and residents.



   (B)   Guidelines and responsibilities.



      (1)   The Chief of Police, or his or her designee, will
identify and recommend locations throughout the city where security cameras
would be necessary and appropriate; the Chief of Police will also regularly
inspect all security cameras to ensure functionality and compliance.



      (2)   Recorded security camera video will be stored in a
secure data storage system that can be accessed only by personnel within the
Hamlet Police Department.



      (3)   Recorded security camera video will be retained in
accordance with G.S. §§ 132-1.4 and 132-1.4A, and the North Carolina Public
Records Retention Schedule.



      (4)   Altering of security camera video is not permitted. The
only exceptions are enhancing image quality for investigative purposes or
blurring features to protect an individual’s privacy.



      (5)   Requests for external review or release of security
camera video must be submitted in writing to the Chief of Police. who will
consult with the City Manager and City Attorney.



(Ord. passed 12-11-2018)



CHAPTER 3:  ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES



Section



   3-1   Unfortified wine; sale permitted



   3-2   Unfortified wine; license required



   3-3   Unfortified wine; privilege tax



   3-4   Unfortified wine; applicability of state regulations



   3-5   Drinking in public places



Cross-reference:



   Licenses and business regulations, see ch. 10



   Motor vehicles and traffic, see ch. 11



Statutory reference:



   Alcoholic Beverages, see G.S. Chapter 18B



§ 3-1  UNFORTIFIED WINE; SALE PERMITTED.



   Any qualified person may sell at retail unfortified wines (wines
containing less than 17% alcohol), either on premises or off premises,
provided that the person meets the qualifications set forth in G.S. §§
18B-100 et seq.



(1972 Code, § 5-17)



Statutory reference:



   Retail wine license, see § G.S. 105-113.77



§ 3-2  UNFORTIFIED WINE; LICENSE REQUIRED.



   Before any person engages in the business of selling unfortified wines
(wines containing less than 17% alcohol), the person shall apply to the
Council for a license to make the sale and shall comply with state law and
regulations in regard thereto.



(1972 Code, § 5-18)



§ 3-3  UNFORTIFIED WINE; PRIVILEGE TAX.



   Taxes shall be levied for the privilege of selling unfortified wines
off the premises and for the privilege of selling unfortified wines on the
premises, as provided in G.S. § 105-113.77.



(1972 Code, § 5-19)



§ 3-4  UNFORTIFIED WINE; APPLICABILITY OF STATE REGULATIONS.



   (A)   Every person who applies for a license to sell unfortified
wines shall meet all of the requirements of state law and especially the
regulations of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission in regard
thereto.



   (B)   The license issued under this section shall be subject to all
the rules and regulations of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission
and state law in regard thereto.



(1972 Code, § 5-20)



§ 3-5  DRINKING IN PUBLIC PLACES.



   (A)   Generally.  No person shall consume malt beverages or
unfortified wine on any property owned or occupied by the city.



(1972 Code, § 15-11)



   (B)   Exceptions.



      (1)   Consumption of beer and wine is permitted in areas
authorized by permit in § 18-14 of this Code.



      (2)   Malt beverages and unfortified wine may be sold and
consumed as part of any event taking place on city property, provided that
the person or group sponsoring the event obtains approval to do so from the
city prior to the date of the event. Any request for permission to sell
and/or consume alcohol on city property shall be submitted in writing at
least ten days prior to consideration of the matter by the City Manager. The
request shall include, at a minimum, the following information:



         (a)   The type of event being held;



         (b)   The date, time, and length of the event;



         (c)   The types of beverages proposed to be sold and/or
consumed;



         (d)   The designation of one or more responsible persons
who shall be onsite during the entire event, including a cell phone number at
which said person(s) may be contacted at any time during the event. The
responsible person shall be a representative of the applicant and shall have
the authority to discontinue alcohol sales and/or consumption at any time
during the event;



         (e)   A description of the approximate area where
alcohol may be sold and/or consumed during the event, and an affirmation that
alcoholic beverages will not be consumed outside of the designated area;



         (f)   If the event is to be open to the public, access
to the event area shall be controlled, and the event sponsor shall affirm
that it will be responsible for checking the identification of patrons prior
to selling or serving alcohol; and



         (g)   The event sponsor shall affirm that prior to the
beginning of the event it will obtain all necessary State or other permits
relating to the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages. The Hamlet Chief
of Police shall review all requests to sell and/or serve alcohol on city
property and shall provide a recommendation to the City Manager as to each
request.



(Ord. passed 1-9-2001; Ord. 2017-07, passed 10-10-2017; Ord. passed
11-13-2018)



Statutory reference:



   Manufacture, sale and the like, forbidden except as expressly
authorized, see G.S. § 18B-102



   Public intoxication, see G.S. §§ 14-443 et seq.



   Purpose of alcoholic beverage law, see G.S. § 18B-100



   Sale, possession and consumption, see G.S. §§ 18B-300 et seq.

ARTICLE I:  IN GENERAL



§ 4-1  BIRDS; SANCTUARY ESTABLISHED.



   The entire area within the city limits is hereby designated as a bird
sanctuary.



(1972 Code, § 15-6)



Statutory reference:



   Bird sanctuaries, see G.S. § 160A-188



§ 4-2  BIRDS; SHOOTING, TRAPPING AND THE LIKE PROHIBITED.



   (A)   No person shall trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot, take,
kill or molest in any manner any bird or wildfowl or shall rob bird nests or
wildfowl nests; provided, that if starlings or similar birds are found to be
congregating in such numbers in a particular locality as to constitute a
nuisance or menace to health or property in the opinion of the proper health
authorities, the health authorities shall meet with the representatives of
the Audubon Society, bird club, garden club or humane society, after having
given at least three days’ actual notice of the time and place of the
meeting to the representatives of the clubs.



   (B)   If as a result of the meeting no satisfactory alternative is
found to abate the nuisance, the birds may be destroyed in those numbers and
in a manner as is deemed advisable by the health authorities under the
supervision of the City Manager.



   (C)   Subsections (A) and (B) above do not protect any birds classed
as a pest under G.S. Chapter 113, Article 22A (G.S. §§ 113-300.1 et seq.)
and the Structural Pest Control Act of North Carolina of 1955 (G.S. §§
106-65.22 et seq.) or the State Pesticide Law of 1971 (G.S. §§ 143-434 et
seq.).



   (D)   Subsections (A) and (B) do not limit the authority of any
person holding a valid permit issued by the State Wildlife Resources
Commission under G.S. § 113-274(c)(1a) or under any other license or permit
of the Wildlife Resources Commission specifically made valid for use in
taking birds within city limits.



(1972 Code, §§ 15-7, 15-8)



§ 4-3  RESTRICTIONS ON KEEPING HOGS, FOWL.



   No person shall keep any hogs or fowl within the city limits.



(1972 Code, § 3-7)  (Ord. passed 2-17-1976)



Statutory reference:



   Feeding garbage to swine, see G.S. §§ 106-405.1 et seq.



§ 4-4  CLEANLINESS OF STABLES AND THE LIKE.



   Every stable and place where cattle, horses or other animals are kept
shall be maintained at all times in a clean and healthful condition.



(1972 Code, § 3-8)  (Ord. passed 2-17-1976)



§ 4-5  RIDING OR DRIVING ANIMALS OVER SIDEWALKS.



   No person shall drive or ride any animal, whether attached to a vehicle
or not, over any sidewalk.



(1972 Code, § 3-9)  (Ord. passed 2-17-1976)



Cross-reference:



   Motor vehicles and traffic, see ch. 11



   Streets and sidewalks, see ch. 18



§ 4-6  DEAD ANIMALS.



   No person shall permit the carcass of any dead animal to remain on
premises owned or controlled by him or her, nor shall any person deposit the
carcass of any dead animal upon any street or the premises of another person.



(1972 Code, § 11-2)



§ 4-7  ANIMALS AT SPECIAL EVENTS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any owner to take an animal into or
allow the animal to enter or remain within the boundaries of a festival,
concert or other public gathering approved by the City Council as a city
sponsored or approved event. The event boundary shall include any area that
is part of the event and shall include any public street, sidewalks or other
publicly owned area within the confines of such event.



   (B)   The following animals are exempt from the prohibitions
contained in division (A) above:



      (1)   Service animals assisting persons who are physically
impaired;



      (2)   Animals under the control of on-duty law enforcement
personnel; and



      (3)   Animals that are part of an authorized exhibit or
attraction approved by the event organizers.



(Ord. passed 4-12-2016)



§ 4-8  TETHERING OF ANIMALS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful to chain, tie, fasten, or otherwise tether any
animal to a stationary object such as trees, posts, fences, and the like.
Animals shall be allowed to be on a running length of tether if they have a
proper fitting collar, the tether is at least four times the length of the
animal’s body, and the animal has access to proper food, water, and shelter.



(Ord. passed 11-9-2010)



ARTICLE II:  ANIMAL CONTROL



§ 4-31  DEFINITIONS.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this article, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning.



   ANIMAL CONTROL REVIEW BOARD.  The City Manager and the Police Chief
shall also serve as the ANIMAL CONTROL REVIEW BOARD in accordance with G.S.
§ 67-4.1(c).



   ANIMAL SHELTER.  A place provided and operated by the county for the
restraint, care and disposition of animals.



   AT LARGE.  Off the premises of the owner, and not under control either
by leash, cord or chain, or without the immediate and effective control of
the owner or other responsible person.



   CONTROL.  Within 50 feet of the owner and not on private property of
others.



   DANGEROUS DOG. A dog that:



      (1)   Without provocation, has killed or inflicted severe
injury on a person; or



      (2)   Is determined by the animal control officer or Animal
Control Board to be potentially dangerous because the dog has engaged in one
or more of the behaviors listed in the definition of “potentially dangerous
dog” below; or



      (3)   Is owned or harbored primarily or in part for the
purpose of dog fighting, or any dog trained for dog fighting.



   DOG.  Both male and female dogs over the age of four months.



   OWNER.  Any person or legal entity that has a possessory property
right in a dog. For the purposes of this article, the head of the household
shall be deemed to be the OWNER in respect to any dog or dogs owned, kept or
harbored by any person residing in the household and kept on the premises.



   OWNER'S REAL PROPERTY.  Any real property owned or leased by the owner
of the dog, but does not include any public right-of-way or a common area of
a condominium, apartment complex, or townhouse development.



   POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS DOG.  A dog that the person or Board designated
by the county or municipal authority responsible for animal control
determines to have:



      (1)   Inflicted a bite on a person that resulted in broken
bones, disfiguring lacerations, or required cosmetic surgery or
hospitalization; or



      (2)   Killed or inflicted severe injury upon a domestic animal
when not on the owner’s real property; or



      (3)   Approached a person when not on the owner’s property
in a vicious or terrorizing manner in an apparent attitude of attack.



   SEVERE INJURY. Any physical injury that results in broken bones,
disfiguring lacerations, or required cosmetic surgery or hospitalization.



   VICIOUS DOG.  Any dog which has bitten one or more persons without
provocation, or one in which a propensity to attack humans exists and the
propensity is known or ought to reasonably be known to the owner.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



Cross-reference:



   Definitions and rules of construction generally, see § 1-2



Statutory reference:



   Confinement of biting dogs and cats, notice to local health director,
report by physician, see G.S. § 130A-196



   Dangerous dogs, see G.S. §§ 67-41 through 67.4.5



   Infected dogs and cats to be destroyed, protection of vaccinated dogs
and cats, see G.S. § 130A-197



   Rabies, see G.S. §§ 130A-184 et seq.



   Vaccination of dogs and cats, see G.S. §§ 130A-185, 130A-193



§ 4-32  ANIMAL CONTROL AGENCY; CREATION.



   There is hereby created an Animal Control Division for the city, which
shall consist of a(an) animal control officer(s) within the city’s Police
Department. Each animal control officer shall work under the supervision of
the Police Chief, or his or her designee.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



Cross-reference:



   Administration, see ch. 2



§ 4-33  ANIMAL CONTROL AGENCY; DUTIES.



   The Animal Control Division shall be charged with the responsibility of:



   (A)   Enforcement of the city laws, ordinances and resolutions
relating to cats and dogs, or to the care, custody and control of animals;



   (B)   Cooperation with the county agencies in the enforcement of the
laws of the state with regard to dogs and to the confinement and leashing of
dangerous animals. Reference is particularly made to the state laws as set
out and contained in G.S. §§ 67-1 through 67-18 and 130A-184 et seq.; and



   (C)   Investigations of reported and observed cruelty or animal
abuse with regard to cats, dogs and other animals, within the city limits,
pursuant to the provisions of G.S. § 14-360.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



Cross-reference:



   Administration, see ch. 2



§ 4-34  KEEPING OF DOGS.



   (A)   Dangerous dogs.  It shall be unlawful for any owner to keep
any dangerous dog within the city limits.



   (B)   Running at large.  It shall be unlawful for any owner to
allow any dog of his or her to run at large within the city limits. When
walking dogs, they must be under leash or control, and the owner shall not
permit the dog to enter on or disturb in any manner the property of others
even though under leash.



   (C)   Female dogs in heat.  It shall be unlawful for the owner of
any female dog in heat to keep the same within the city limits during that
period, unless confined to the premises of the owner or other person with
that person’s consent.



   (D)   Dogs creating nuisances.  It shall be unlawful for any owner
to keep on his or her lot or premises any dog or dogs that result in
unsanitary conditions, or that bark, howl, fight or make other noises as to
disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood or the general public, and
result in a neighborhood or public nuisance. Failure to abate the same upon
warning from the Chief of Police, or his or her duly authorized
representative, or the an animal control officer, will be a misdemeanor
subject to punishment as indicated in § 1-6.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



Statutory reference:



   Permitting bitch at large, see G.S. § 67-2



   Permitting dogs to run at large at night, see § G.S. 67-12



§ 4-35  RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNERS.



   Owners of dogs are responsible for the acts of their dogs. The owner of
any dog who commits a nuisance upon the property of another person, or who
damages another person’s property or person, is fully responsible and
accountable for these acts.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



§ 4-36  IMPOUNDING STRAY DOGS; REDEMPTION, SALE OR DESTRUCTION; DISPOSITION
OF FUNDS.



   (A)   Any dog within the city without an owner, turned in as
provided in § 4-40, or any dog running at large shall be taken by the animal
control officer and confined in the animal shelter controlled by the county
for a period established by the county for redemption by the owner.



   (B)   Complete and accurate records of all activities is the
responsibility of the county as indicated in paragraph IV of the Richmond
County Rabies Control Program, September 9, 1975.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



§ 4-37  BARKING DOGS.



   It shall be unlawful for any dog owner to keep or have within the city
a dog that habitually or repeatedly barks in a manner or to an extent that it
is a public nuisance as defined in § 4-34.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



§ 4-38  TEASING AND MOLESTING.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to tease, molest, bait or in any
way bother any dog not belonging to him or her or legally under his or her
control.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



Statutory reference:



   Cruelty to animals, see G.S. §§ 14-360 et seq.



§ 4-39  MAINTENANCE OF DOG LOTS, PENS AND THE LIKE.



   Every person who owns or maintains any pen, lot, shelter or other place
where dogs are kept shall maintain same in a clean, sanitary condition which
precludes drifting of odors beyond boundaries of his or her own property and
to include providing shelter from inclement weather for the animal(s).



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



§ 4-40  KEEPING STRAY DOGS; REQUIREMENTS, FAILURE TO SURRENDER.



   It shall be unlawful for any person in the city knowingly and
intentionally to harbor, feed, keep in possession by confinement or otherwise
any dog which does not belong to him or her, unless he or she has, within 48
hours from the time the dog came into his or her possession, notified the
Police Department. Upon receiving the notice, the animal control officer(s)
may take the dog and place it in the shelter, record same and shall deal with
it as provided in § 4-36, and attempt to find the owner.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



§ 4-41  INJURING DOGS; NOTICE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person injuring a dog, by running over or
into same with an automobile, motorcycle, bicycle or other vehicle to fail to
notify, as soon as is reasonably possible, the owner or the Police Department.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



§ 4-42  IMPOUNDED ANIMALS; NOTIFICATION OF OWNER.



   Immediately upon impounding an animal from the city, the animal shelter
personnel shall attempt to notify the owner by telephone and inform him or
her of the conditions whereby the animal may be redeemed.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



§ 4-43  RABIES CONTROL; REPORTING OF DOG BITES, OBSERVATION PERIOD.



   (A)   Notice of bite.  When a person has been bitten by an animal
required to be vaccinated by state law, the person or parent, guardian or
person standing in loco parentis of the person, and the person owning the
animal or in control or possession of the animal shall notify the animal
control officer and the county health director immediately and give the name
and address of the person bitten and the owner of the animal. If the animal
that bites a person is a stray or feral animal, the animal control officer
shall make a reasonable attempt to locate the owner of the animal. If the
owner cannot be identified within 72 hours of the event, the county health
director may authorize the animal be euthanized, and the head of the animal
shall be immediately sent to the State Laboratory of Public Health for rabies
diagnosis. If the event occurs on a weekend or state holiday, the time period
for owner identification shall be extended 24 hours.



   (B)   Physician report. A physician who attends a person bitten by
an animal known to be a potential carrier of rabies shall report the incident
within 24 hours to the animal control officer and the county health director.
The report must include the name, age, and sex of the person.



   (C)   Confinement. As required by G.S. §§ 130A-196 and 130A-198, a
person who owns or has possession of an animal suspected of having rabies
shall immediately notify the animal control officer and the county health
director, and shall securely confine the animal in a place designated by the
health director. The animal shall be confined for a period of ten days.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



Statutory reference:



   Rabies control, see G.S. §§ 130A-196 through 130A-198



§ 4-44  RECORDS.



   It shall be the duty of the county animal control officer(s) to keep,
or cause to be kept, accurate and detailed records as outlined in paragraph
IV of the County Rabies Control Program.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



§ 4-45  POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS DOGS AND DANGEROUS DOGS.



   (A)   Determination. The animal control officer shall determine when
a dog is “potentially dangerous” or “dangerous,” as defined in §
4-31.



   (B)   Precautions against attacks by dangerous dogs.



      (1)   It is unlawful for an owner to:



         (a)   Leave a dangerous dog unattended on the owner’s
real property, unless the dog is confined indoors, in a securely enclosed and
locked pen, or in another structure designed to restrain the dog;



         (b)   Permit a dangerous dog to go beyond the owner’s
real property, unless the dog is leashed and muzzled or is otherwise securely
restrained and muzzled.



      (2)   Transfer of ownership. If the owner of a dangerous dog
transfers ownership or possession of the dog to another person (as defined in
G.S. § 12-3(6)), the owner shall provide written notice to:



         (a)   The animal control officer, stating the name,
street address and mailing address of the new owner or possessor of the dog;
and



         (b)   The person taking ownership or possession of the
dog, specifying the dog’s dangerous behavior and the animal control
officer’s determination.



      (3)   Per G.S. § 67-4.2, violation of this subsection 4-45(B)
is a Class 3 misdemeanor.



   (C)   Penalty for attacks by dangerous dogs. Per G.S. § 67-4.3, the
owner of a dangerous dog that attacks a person and causes physical injuries
requiring medical treatment in excess of $100 shall be guilty of a Class 1
misdemeanor.



   (D)   Strict liability. Per G.S. § 67-4.4., the owner of a
dangerous dog shall be strictly liable in civil damages for any injuries or
property damage the dog inflicts upon a person, his or her property, or
another animal.



   (E)   The provisions of this § 4-45 do not apply to:



      (1)   A dog being used by a law enforcement officer to carry
out the law enforcement officer’s official duties;



      (2)   A dog being used in a lawful hunt;



      (3)   A dog, where the injury or damage inflicted by the dog
was sustained by a domestic animal, while the dog was working as a hunting
dog, herding dog, or predator control dog on the property of, or under the
control of, its owner or keeper, and the damage or injury was to a species or
type of domestic animal appropriate to the work of the dog; or



      (4)   A dog, where the injury inflicted by the dog was
sustained by a person who, at the time of the injury, was committing a
willful trespass or other tort, was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the
dog, had tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog, or was committing or
attempting to commit a crime.



   (F)   Notice and right to appeal.  Before a dog may be considered
potentially dangerous, the animal control officer must notify the owner of
the dog, in writing, that the officer believes the dog to be potentially
dangerous. The written notice must give the reasons for the determination.
The owner may appeal the determination by filing written objections with the
Animal Control Review Board within three days of receipt of the notice. The
owner may file written objections by delivering them to the animal control
officer, who shall then transmit the objections to the Board.



   (G)   Animal Control Review Board. The Board shall schedule a
hearing within ten days of the filing of the objections. The hearing shall be
quasi-judicial in nature, and the burden shall at all times be on the owner
to prove that the decision of the animal control officer should be reversed
or modified.



   (H)   Appeal to Superior Court.  The owner or the city may appeal
the final decision of the Animal Control Review Board to the Richmond County
Superior Court, by filing a notice of appeal and a petition for review within
ten days of the issuance of the Animal Control Review Board’s final written
decision. Appeals from rulings of the Animal Control Review Board shall be de
novo before a superior court judge sitting in Richmond County.



(Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



Statutory reference:



   Dangerous dogs, see G.S. §§ 67-4.1 through 67-4.5.



§ 4-46  VIOLATIONS; INTERFERENCE WITH ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICERS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, hinder or molest
the animal control officer(s) in the performance of any duty authorized by
this article, or to seek to release any animal in the custody of the agent.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



§ 4-47  PENALTY.



   Any owner found violating any provisions of this article shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as
provided in § 1-6.



(Ord. passed 2-17-1976; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07, passed 9-8-2015)



§ 4-48  FINES.



   Fines for violations to the Code as it relates to animals will be
assessed as follows:



 

First offense
 

$50



Second offense
 

$100



Third offense
 

$250



Each subsequent offense thereafter
 

$500




 



(per vote of City Council, 11-9-2010; Ord. passed 8-11-2015; Ord. 2015-07,
passed 9-8-2015)

ARTICLE I:  IN GENERAL



§ 5-1  SCOPE.



   (A)   The provisions of this chapter and of the regulatory Codes
herein shall apply to the following:



      (1)   The location, design, materials, equipment,
construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, maintenance, moving,
demolition, removal, use and occupancy of every building or structure or any
appurtenances connected or attached to the building or structure;



      (2)   The installation, erection, alteration, repair, use and
maintenance of plumbing systems consisting of house sewers, building drains,
waste and vent systems, hot and cold water supply systems and all fixtures
and appurtenances thereof;



      (3)   The installation, erection, alteration, repair, use and
maintenance of mechanical systems consisting of heating, ventilating, air
conditioning and refrigeration systems, fuel burning equipment and
appurtenances thereof; and



      (4)   The installation, erection, alteration, repair, use and
maintenance of electrical systems and appurtenances thereof.



   (B)   The adoption of this chapter and the Codes herein adopted by
reference shall constitute a resolution within the meaning of G.S. §
143-138(b) making the regulatory Codes herein adopted applicable to dwellings
and outbuildings used in connection therewith and to apartment buildings used
exclusively as the residence of not more than two families.



§ 5-2  REGISTRATION OF CONTRACTORS; REQUIRED.



   Every person carrying on the business of building contractor, plumbing
contractor, heating and air conditioning contractor or electrical contractor
within the city shall register at the County Building Inspections Department
in Rockingham, giving his or her name and place of business.



Cross-reference:



   Licenses and business regulations, see ch. 10



§ 5-3  REGISTRATION OF CONTRACTORS; BOND.



   Every person required to register at the County Building Inspector’s
office under § 5-2 shall also give sufficient evidence of license in the
state.



§ 5-4  PERMITS.



   Permits are required to be obtained through the Richmond County
Building Inspections Department. The city follows the North Carolina Building
Code.



ARTICLE II:  CODES ADOPTED



§ 5-36  MOBILE HOME CODE.



   The Mobile Homes-Modular Dwelling Units and Other Factory Built
Structures Code promulgated by the state is hereby adopted and shall be
applicable to units made after July 1, 1970.  Mobile homes allowed inside
the city limits may not be over 12 years of age.



§ 5-37  BUILDING CODE.



   The State Building Code, Volume I, General Construction, with current
amendments, is hereby adopted by reference as the Building Code of the city
to the extent the Code is applicable for safe and stable design, methods of
construction, minimum standards and use of materials in buildings hereafter
erected, enlarged, altered, repaired or otherwise constructed or
reconstructed.



§ 5-38  PLUMBING CODE.



   The State Plumbing Code (State Building Code, Volume II, Plumbing),
with current amendments, is hereby adopted by reference as the Plumbing Code
for the city.



Cross-reference:



   Water and sewers, see ch. 21



§ 5-39  HEATING CODE.



   The State Plumbing Code (State Building Code, Volume III, Heating),
with current amendments, is hereby adopted by reference as the Heating Code
for the city.



§ 5-40  ELECTRICAL CODE.



   The current edition of the State Electrical Code (State Building Code,
Volume IV, Electrical), adopting by reference the current edition of the
National Fire Protection Association, with current amendments, is hereby
adopted by reference as the Electrical Code for the city.



§ 5-41  RESIDENTIAL BUILDING CODE.



   The State Uniform Residential Building Code, with current amendments,
as adopted by the State Building Inspectors Association and as published by
the State Building Code Council is hereby adopted by reference as the
Residential Building Code for one- and two-family residential buildings in
the city.



§ 5-42  AMENDMENTS TO CODES.



   Amendments to the regulatory Codes adopted by reference in this
article, which are from time to time adopted and published by the agencies or
organizations referred to herein, shall be effective in the city at the time
the amendments are filed with the County Building Inspector’s office.



§ 5-43  COMPLIANCE WITH CODES.



   (A)   All buildings or structures which are hereafter constructed,
reconstructed, erected, altered, extended, enlarged, repaired, demolished or
moved shall conform to the requirements, minimum standards and other
provisions of either the Building Code, or the Residential Building Code,
whichever is applicable, or of both.



   (B)   Every building or structure intended for human habitation,
occupancy or use shall have plumbing, plumbing systems or plumbing fixtures
installed, constructed, altered, extended, repaired or reconstructed in
accordance with the minimum standards, requirements and other provisions of
the Plumbing Code.



   (C)   All mechanical systems consisting of heating, ventilating, air
conditioning and refrigeration systems, fuel burning equipment and
appurtenances shall be installed, erected, altered, repaired, used and
maintained in accordance with the minimum standards, requirements and other
provisions of the Heating Code.



   (D)   All electrical wiring, installations and appurtenances shall
be erected, altered, repaired, used and maintained in accordance with the
minimum standards, requirements and other provisions of the Electrical Code.



§ 5-44  OFFICIAL COPIES OF CODES FILED WITH COUNTY BUILDING INSPECTOR’S
OFFICE.



   An official copy of each regulatory Code adopted in this article and
official copies of all amendments thereto shall be kept on file in the County
Building Inspector’s office. These copies shall be the official copies of
the Codes and the amendments.



ARTICLE III:  INSPECTION DEPARTMENT



§ 5-66  ORGANIZATION.



   The Inspection Department shall consist of a Building Inspector, a
Plumbing Inspector, a Heating and Air Conditioning Inspector, an Electrical
Inspector and those other Inspectors or assistant Inspectors as may be
authorized by the Council as follows.



   (A)   The Council authorizes the County Building Inspections
Division to enforce the State Building Code in its city limits and
extraterritorial area.



   (B)   The Council agrees to provide the Inspections Division with
all administrative materials and assistance as it may need to properly adhere
to all local ordinances.



   (C)   The County Inspections Division will enforce all Codes of the
city.



§ 5-67  DUTIES GENERALLY.



   (A)   The Inspection Department shall enforce all of the provisions
of this chapter and to make all inspections necessary to determine whether or
not the provisions of this chapter are being met.



   (B)   The Building Code and the Residential Building Code shall be
enforced by the Building Inspector.



   (C)   The Plumbing Code shall be enforced by the Plumbing Inspector.



   (D)   The Heating Code shall be enforced by the Heating and Air
Conditioning Inspector.



   (E)   The Electrical Code shall be enforced by the Electrical
Inspector.



Statutory reference:



   Duties of Inspection Department, see G.S. § 160A-412



§ 5-68  ADDITIONAL ENFORCEMENT DUTIES; DWELLINGS UNFIT FOR HUMAN HABITATION.



   The Inspection Department shall enforce any ordinances or Codes adopted
by the Council relating to the repair, closing and demolition of dwellings
unfit for human habitation pursuant to G.S. §§ 160A-441 et seq. and as
specified in the minimum housing requirements as set forth in the State
Building Code.



§ 5-69  ADDITIONAL ENFORCEMENT DUTIES; ZONING.



   (A)   If the Inspection Department is charged with enforcing the
zoning ordinance of the city, no permit for alteration, repair or
construction of any building shall be issued unless the plans and
specifications show that the building and its proposed use will be in
compliance with applicable provisions of the zoning ordinance.



   (B)   If the Inspection Department is not charged with enforcing the
zoning ordinance, no permit for alteration, repair or construction of any
building shall be issued unless a zoning permit has first been issued by the
appropriate official charged with enforcing the zoning ordinance.



Editor’s note:



   The zoning ordinance is kept in the office of the City Clerk.



§ 5-70  POWERS OF INSPECTORS.



   (A)   Authority.  Inspectors are hereby authorized, empowered and
directed to enforce all the provisions of this chapter.



   (B)   Right of entry.  Inspectors shall have the right of entry on
any premises within the jurisdiction of the regulatory Codes adopted in this
chapter at reasonable hours for the purpose of inspection or enforcement of
the requirements of this chapter.



   (C)   Stop orders.  Whenever any building or part thereof is being
demolished, constructed, reconstructed, altered or repaired in a hazardous
manner, or in violation of any provision of this chapter or any other city
ordinance, or in violation of any provision of any regulatory Code adopted in
this chapter, or in violation of the terms of the permit issued therefor, or
in a manner as to endanger life or property, the appropriate Inspector may
order the work to be stopped immediately. The order shall be in writing to
the owner of the property or his or her agent or to the person doing the work
and shall state the reasons therefor and the conditions under which the work
may be resumed.



§ 5-71  CONFLICTS OF INTEREST.



   No officer or employee of the Inspection Department shall be
financially interested in the furnishing of labor, material or appliances for
the construction, alteration or maintenance of a building or any part thereof
or in the making of plans or specifications therefor, unless he or she is the
owner of the building. No officer or employee of the Inspection Department
shall engage in any work which is inconsistent with his or her duties or with
the interests of the city.



Statutory reference:



   Similar provisions, see G.S. § 160A-415



§ 5-72  REPORTS AND RECORDS.



   The Inspection Department and each Inspector shall keep complete,
permanent and accurate records in convenient form of all applications
received, permits issued, inspections and reinspections made and all other
work and activities of the Department. Periodic reports shall be submitted to
the City Manager and to other agencies as required.



Statutory reference:



   Similar provisions, see G.S. § 160A-433



§ 5-73  INSPECTION OF WORK IN PROGRESS; REQUIRED GENERALLY.



   (A)   The Inspection Department shall inspect all buildings and work
therein for which a permit of any kind has been issued as often as necessary
in order to determine whether the work complies with this chapter.



   (B)   When deemed necessary by the appropriate Inspector, materials
and assemblies may be inspected at the point of manufacture or fabrication,
or inspections may be made by approved and recognized inspection
organizations; provided, that no approval shall be based upon reports of
these organizations unless the same are in writing and certified by a
responsible officer of the organization.



   (C)   All holders of permits, or their agents, shall notify the
Inspection Department and the appropriate Inspector at each of the following
stages of construction so that approval may be given before work is continued:



      (1)   Foundation inspection, to be made after trenches are
excavated and the necessary reinforcement and forms are in place and before
concrete is placed. Drilled footings, piles and similar types of foundations
shall be inspected as installed;



      (2)   Framing inspection, to be made after all structural
framing is in place and all roughing-in of plumbing and electrical and
heating has been installed; after all fire blocking, chimneys, bracing and
vents are installed; but before any of the structure is enclosed or covered.
Poured-in-place concrete structural elements shall be inspected before each
pour of any structural member;



      (3)   Fireproofing inspection, to be made after all areas
required to be protected by fireproofing are lathed, but before the
plastering or other fireproofing is applied; and



      (4)   Final inspection, to be made after the building has all
doors hung and fixtures set and is ready for occupancy, but before the
building is occupied.



Cross-reference:



   Fire prevention and protection, see ch. 9



Statutory reference:



   Similar provisions, see G.S. § 160A-420



§ 5-74  INSPECTION OF WORK IN PROGRESS; REQUESTS.



   (A)   Requests for inspections may be made to the county building
inspection office or to the appropriate Inspector. The Inspection Department
shall make inspections as soon as practicable after a request is made
therefor; provided that the work is ready for inspection at the time the
request is made.



   (B)   Reinspections may be made at the convenience of the Inspector.
No work shall be inspected until it is in proper and completed condition
ready for inspection. All work which has been concealed before the inspection
and approval shall be uncovered at the request of the Inspector and placed in
condition for proper inspection. Approval or rejection of the work shall be
furnished by the appropriate Inspector in the form of a notice posted on the
building or given to the permit holder or his or her agent. Failure to call
for inspections or proceeding without approval at each stage of construction
shall be deemed a violation of this chapter.



§ 5-75  INSPECTION OF WORK IN PROGRESS; SURVEY OF STREET LINES.



   Where the applicant for a permit proposes to erect any building or
structure on the line of any street or other public place, he or she shall
secure a survey of the line of the street or other public place, adjacent to
the property upon which the building or structure is to be erected before
proceeding with construction of the building. The Building Inspector shall
see that the building does not encroach upon the street or other public place.



Cross-reference:



   Streets and sidewalks, see ch. 18



§ 5-76  INSPECTION OF WORK IN PROGRESS; CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY.



   (A)   No new building or part thereof, no addition or enlargement of
any existing building and no existing building after being altered or moved
shall be occupied and no change of occupancy shall be made in any existing
building or part thereof until the Inspection Department has issued a
certificate of occupancy therefor. A temporary certificate of occupancy may
be issued for a portion of a building which may safely be occupied prior to
final completion and occupancy of the entire building.



   (B)   Application for a certificate of occupancy may be made by the
owner or his or her agent after all final inspections have been made for new
buildings, or, in the case of existing buildings, after supplying the
information and data necessary to determine compliance with this chapter and
zoning regulations for the occupancy intended. The Inspection Department
shall issue a certificate of occupancy when, after examination and
inspection, it is found that the building in all respects conforms to the
provisions of this chapter and zoning regulations for the occupancy intended.



Editor’s note:



   The zoning ordinance is kept in the office of the City Clerk.



§ 5-77  OVERSIGHT OF INSPECTOR DOES NOT LEGALIZE VIOLATION.



   No oversight or dereliction of duty on the part of any Inspector or
other official or employee of the Inspection Department shall be deemed to
legalize the violation of any provision of this chapter.



ARTICLE IV:  MINIMUM HOUSING AND UNSAFE BUILDING CODE



DIVISION I:  GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 5-101  INTENT AND FINDINGS OF THE CITY COUNCIL.



   (A)   It is hereby found and declared that the existence and
occupation of dwellings in this city’s jurisdiction that are unfit for
human habitation are inimical to the welfare and dangerous and injurious to
the health, safety and morals of the people of this city and county, and that
a public necessity exists for the repair, closing or demolition of such
dwellings. Whenever this city finds that there exists in the city dwellings
that are unfit for human habitation due to dilapidation, defects increasing
the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities, lack of ventilation,
light or sanitary facilities, or due to other conditions rendering the
dwellings unsafe or unsanitary, or dangerous or detrimental to the health,
safety, morals, or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of the
city; and



   (B)   It is hereby found that when there exists within the city’s
jurisdiction structures that the Board of Commissioners find to be hazardous
to the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the city due to the
attraction of insects and/or snakes and/or rodents, or conditions creating a
fire hazard, dangerous conditions constituting a threat to children, or
conditions creating frequent use by vagrants as living quarters in the
absence of sanitary facilities;



   (C)   Therefore, the city is authorized by G.S. §§ 160A-426 and
160A-441 to exercise its police powers to repair, close or demolish the
dwellings in the manner herein provided. Pursuant to the authority granted by
G.S. §§ 160A-193, 160A-426 and 160A-441, it is the further intent of this
article to provide for the repair, closing or demolition of any such unsafe
or unsanitary dwellings, and abandoned structures in accordance with the
provisions as are set forth in this article for the repair, closing or
demolition of dwellings and/or structures, and to establish minimum standards
of fitness for the initial and continued occupancy of all buildings used for
human habitation.



(Ord. 2015-09, passed 11-10-2015)



§ 5-102  PURPOSE AND SCOPE.



   (A)   The purpose of this article is to stop, remedy and prevent the
decay and deterioration of places of habitation and to eliminate blighted
neighborhoods by providing minimum requirements for dwellings for the
protection of life, health, safety, welfare and property of the owners and
occupants of dwellings and the general public.



   (B)   Additionally, the purpose of this article is to stop, remedy
and prevent the decay and deterioration of places of nonresidential buildings
and structures for the protection of life, health, safety, welfare and
property of the owners and occupants of nonresidential buildings and the
general public.



   (C)   The provisions of this article apply to all residential
buildings, and their accessory structures, all nonresidential buildings and
structures within the city’s jurisdiction as now or may later be fixed.
Demountable buildings or structures when used, or intended to be used, for
human habitation, shall be subject to the applicable provisions of this
article.



(Ord. 2015-09, passed 11-10-2015)



§ 5-103  OWNER’S RESPONSIBILITIES GENERALLY.



   (A)   An owner remains liable for duties imposed by the chapter,
even though:



      (1)   An obligation is also imposed on the occupants; or



      (2)   The owner has, by agreement, imposed on the occupant(s)
the duty of furnishing required equipment or complying with this article.



   (B)   Public areas. Every owner of a dwelling containing two or more
dwelling units shall be responsible for maintaining in a clean and sanitary
condition the shared or public area of the dwelling and premises thereof.



   (C)   ln all cases, the owner shall be responsible for the
availability of rubbish and garbage storage facilities.



   (D)   It shall be a defense to § 5-102 et seq. that violations of
this article were caused solely by a tenant(s) or tenants’ guests. Owner(s)
are responsible for ensuring that the dwelling or building is brought into
compliance with this article.



(Ord. 2015-09, passed 11-10-2015)



§ 5-104  OCCUPANTS’ RESPONSIBILITIES GENERALLY.



   Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall:



   (A)   Cleanliness.  Keep that part of his or her dwelling and
dwelling unit and premises thereof he or she occupies and controls in a clean
and sanitary condition.



   (B)   Rubbish and garbage.   Dispose of all his or her rubbish and
garbage in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in the supplied storage
facilities.



   (C)   Supplied plumbing fixtures. Keep all supplied plumbing
fixtures therein in a sanitary condition, and be responsible for the exercise
of reasonable care in the proper use and operation of same.



   (D)   Care of facilities, equipment and structure.  Not destroy,
deface or impair any of the facilities or equipment, or any part of the
structure of a dwelling or dwelling unit.



(Ord. 2015-09, passed 11-10-2015)



§ 5-105  CONDITIONS RENDERING RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS UNFIT FOR HUMAN
HABITATION; DECLARATION OF UNSAFE NONRESIDENTIAL BUILDING OR STRUCTURE.



   (A)   Residential buildings.  Every dwelling and dwelling unit used
as a human habitation, or held out for use as a human habitation, shall
comply with all of the minimum standards of fitness for human habitation and
all other applicable requirements of this article.



      (1)   No person shall occupy as owner-occupant, or let to
another for occupancy or use as a human habitation, any dwelling or dwelling
unit that does not comply with all of the minimum standards of fitness for
human habitation and all other applicable requirements of this article.



      (2)   The following standards shall constitute the minimum
standards for the structural condition of a dwelling or dwelling unit. The
Inspector will determine that a residential building is unfit for human
habitation if any of the following conditions exist:



         (a)   Walls or partitions or supporting members, sills,
joists, rafters or other structural members list, lean or buckle, and/or are
rotten, deteriorated or damaged, and/or have holes or cracks that might admit
rodents. Supporting members are not adequate if 33% or more are damaged or
deteriorated. Non-supporting, enclosing or outside walls or coverings are not
adequate if 55% or more are damaged or deteriorated.



         (b)   Floors or roofs have inadequate supporting members
and strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose used. Supporting members
are not adequate if 33% or more are damaged or deteriorated. Non-supporting,
enclosing or outside walls or coverings are not adequate if 55% or more are
damaged or deteriorated.



         (c)   Foundations, foundation walls, piers or other
foundation supports are deteriorated or damaged.



         (d)   Steps, stairs, landings, porches, or other parts
and appurtenances are maintained in such condition that they will fail or
collapse.



         (e)   Adequate facilities for egress in case of fire or
panic are not provided.



         (f)   Interior wails and ceilings of all rooms, closets
and hallways are not furnished of suitable materials, which will by use of
reasonable household methods promote sanitation and cleanliness, and are not
maintained in such manner so as to enable the occupants to maintain
reasonable privacy between various spaces.



         (g)   The roof, flashing, exterior walls, floors, and
all doors and windows exposed to the weather are not constructed and
maintained so as to be weather and watertight.



         (h)   Chimneys or parts thereof are defective,
deteriorated or in danger of falling, or in such condition or location as to
constitute a fire hazard.



         (i)   The ground is used for floors, or wood floors are
on the ground.



      (3)   Irrespective of § 5-105(A)(2) above, the enforcing
agent shall find residential dwelling units to be unfit for human habitation
if a dwelling unit contains more than five separate types of violations of
any of the minimum standards set forth in this article.



   (B)   Both residential and abandoned buildings and structures1. 
Every structure within the city’s jurisdiction shall be deemed in violation
of this article whenever it constitutes a hazard to the health, safety or
welfare of the city’s citizens. The enforcing agent may declare an
abandoned and/or residential structure or building to be unsafe as a result
of:



      (1)   Vacancy or abandonment;



      (2)   Dilapidated conditions causing or contributing to
blight, disease and/or safety hazards;



      (3)   The attraction of insects and/or rodents and/or snakes,
including the collection of garbage or rubbish in or near the structure that
might attract rodents and/or snakes and/or insects, or become breeding places
for rodents and/or snakes and/or insects;



      (4)   Conditions creating a fire hazard;



      (5)   Dangerous conditions constituting a threat to children,
such as the use of the structure by children as a play area, or violations of
the State Building Code that might result in danger to children using the
structure as a play area if the structure is also vacant and abandoned. If
the structure meets the criteria of the preceding sentence and is within a
community development area, then the structure may be declared unsafe;
