   Fire prevention and protection, see ch. 9



   Parades, picketing and demonstrations, see ch. 15



   Swimming pools, see ch. 19



Statutory reference:



   Boating and water safety, see G.S. Chapter 75A



   Conservation of marine and estuarine and wildlife resources, see G.S.
§§ 113-127 et seq.



   Municipal parks and recreation, see G.S. §§ 160A-350 et seq.



ARTICLE I:  IN GENERAL



§ 12-1  DEFINITION.



   As used in this chapter, CITY LAKE means the lake located north of
Hamlet Avenue between Veteran’s Drive and Second Street.



(Ord. passed 7-1-1975)



Cross-reference:



   Definitions and rules of construction generally, see § 1-2



§ 12-2  CUSTODIAN; ISSUANCE OF PERMITS.



   The Council or person duly authorized by the Council shall be made
custodian of the city lake, the ballpark and fairground and have the
authority to grant permits for the use of the same.



(1972 Code, § 13-1)



§ 12-3  COUNCIL APPROVAL MAY BE REQUIRED FOR PERMIT.



   Nothing in this chapter shall give the City Manager the right to issue
permits to any person to use the facilities when a provision of this Code or
an ordinance of the city requires approval of the Council before a permit can
be issued.



(1972 Code, § 13-3)



§ 12-4  FEES FOR USE OF BALLPARK, FAIRGROUND.



   The fees for the use of the city ballpark and fairground shall be set
by the Council.



(1972 Code, § 13-2)



§ 12-5  CLOSING HOURS.



   (A)   All public parks and public recreational facilities within the
city limits shall be closed to the public between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and
daylight except for organized and duly scheduled recreational activities.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person except for law enforcement
officers and duly authorized city employees to go upon the grounds of any
public park, playground or recreational facility within the city limits
within the times prohibited in this section, and all persons not excepted by
this subsection found to be upon the premises at prohibited times shall be
deemed trespassers and prosecuted under the laws of the state for trespassing.



(Ord. passed 7-14-1981)



ARTICLE II:  MUNICIPAL LAKES



§ 12-31  USE SUBJECT TO REGULATIONS.



   The city lake shall be closed to fishing, boating or other uses, except
as permitted in this chapter.



(1972 Code, § 13-4)



§ 12-32  POSTING OF NOTICES, SIGNS.



   Proper notices and signs shall be posted in conspicuous places on city
lake property warning the public that the property has been posted and use is
prohibited except in the manner described in this chapter.



(1972 Code, § 13-5)



§ 12-33  PERMIT; REQUIRED.



   Any person who desires to use the city lake in accordance with the
terms and conditions of this chapter shall first secure from the City Manager
or his or her designated agent a permit and pay the charges as provided in
this chapter.



(1972 Code, § 13-6)



§ 12-34  PERMIT; REVOCATION.



   (A)   The Council shall have the right to revoke any permit issued
under this chapter for any reason deemed sufficient by the Council for
revocation of the same, and the decision of the Council shall be final.



   (B)   Upon the revocation of any permit, the City Manager or his or
her designated agent shall refund the proportionate share of the cost of the
permit.



(1972 Code, § 13-8)



§ 12-35  APPLICABILITY OF STATE FISHING REGULATIONS.



   No person shall fish in the city lake in any manner that violates the
laws of the state or of the rules and regulations of the State Department of
Environment, Health and Natural Resources.



(1972 Code, § 13-9)



§ 12-36  TAKING MINNOWS FROM LAKE; LIMITED.



   No person shall catch more than 50 minnows from the city lake during
any 24-hour period.



(1972 Code, § 13-10)



§ 12-37  TAKING MINNOWS FROM LAKE; SALE PROHIBITED.



   No person shall sell or offer for sale any minnows caught from the city
lake.



(1972 Code, § 13-11)



§ 12-38  BAN OF MOTORIZED BOATS FROM CITY LAKE.



   All gasoline powered motors (motorized boats) are banned from the city
lake with the exception of purposes for local, state or governmental agencies
as permitted.



(1972 Code, § 13-12)  (Ord. passed 3-1-2008)



§ 12-39  SWIMMING, WADING AND DIVING PROHIBITED.



   No person shall use the city lake for wading, swimming or diving
purposes.



(1972 Code, § 13-13)



§ 12-40  CONSTRUCTION PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No construction of piers, of rafts or of any other nature shall be
permitted on the city lake except by the express permission of the Council.



(1972 Code, § 13-14)



§ 12-41  PERMISSION REQUIRED FOR COMMERCIAL USE.



   No person shall make commercial use of the city lake except by specific
permission given by the Council, and no license for any commercial purpose
shall be issued until the application has been made in writing to the Council.



(1972 Code, § 13-15)



§ 12-42  COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS; LIABILITY FOR DAMAGE.



   Any person using the city lake shall do so under the provisions
provided in this article and shall assume all risk in connection with any
injuries or damage to boats, skiers or occupants of boats.



(1972 Code, § 13-16)



§ 12-43  CONTAMINATION, POLLUTION AND THE LIKE PROHIBITED.



   No person shall be allowed to contaminate, pollute or otherwise damage
the city lake property.



(1972 Code, § 13-17)



§ 12-44  MINORS RESTRICTED.



   No person under 18 years of age shall be allowed to use or operate a
boat on the city lake; but parents, guardians or other persons having custody
and control of minors under 18 years of age may take their own children or
wards with them, and any other person over 18 years of age, with written
permission of a minor’s parent, guardian or custodian, may carry minors
under 18 years of age with them.



(1972 Code, § 13-18)



§ 12-45  NIGHT FISHING PROHIBITED.



   Fishing at the city lake shall be prohibited at night between sunset
and sunrise.



(Ord. passed 7-1-1975)



§ 12-46  FISHING WITH JUGS, TROTLINES, NETS.



   It shall be unlawful to fish with jugs, trotlines and nets in the city
lake.



(Ord. passed 7-1-1975)



§ 12-47  FISHING PROHIBITED IN CITY WATER RESERVOIR.



   All types of fishing are hereby prohibited in the city water reservoir
located between Wellington Road and Boyd Lake Road, approximately two miles
north of the city limits, and in and upon the streams entering and exiting
the reservoir located on city property.



(1972 Code, § 13-20)



§ 12-48  ENFORCEMENT.



   The police officers of the city and all of the game wardens operating
under the supervision of the state or any other lawful officer may enforce
the provisions of this article.



(1972 Code, § 13-19)



ARTICLE III:  CONDUCT IN PUBLIC PARKS



§ 12-71  DEFINITIONS.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning.



   PARK.  A park, reservation, playground, community center, recreation
center, stadium or any other area or structure in the city, owned, leased or
used by the city or the Council and devoted to active or passive recreation,
including property owned by others and devoted to park purposes under the
jurisdiction of the city.



   VEHICLE.  Any wheeled conveyance, whether motor-operated, animal-drawn
or self-propelled; except wheelchairs and similar vehicles, baby carriages
and vehicles in the service of the city parks. (Ord. passed 9-17-1991)



Cross-reference:



   Definitions and rules of construction generally, see § 1-2



§ 12-72  PARK PROPERTY.



   (A)   Buildings and other property.  No person in a park shall:



      (1)   Willfully mark, deface, disfigure, adulterate, injure,
tamper with, displace or remove any buildings, bridges, tables, benches,
fireplaces, railings, swimming pools or wading pools, paving or paving
material, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances
thereof, fences, signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or permanent,
receptacles, monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers or other
structures, improvements or equipments, facilities or park property or
appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal;



      (2)   Force entry into any restroom or washroom that is locked
or bolted; and no person over the age of five years shall use any restroom,
washroom or locker room designated for the opposite sex;



      (3)   Dig, or remove any soil, rock or stones (except in areas
designated for that purpose) or any trees, shrubs, plants, planting, grass,
down-timber or other wood or materials, or make any excavation by tool,
equipment, blasting or other means of or agency; or



      (4)   Construct or erect any building or structure of whatever
kind, whether permanent or temporary in character, or run or string any
public service utility into, upon or across those lands, except on special
written permit issued under this article.



   (B)   Trees, shrubbery, lawns.  No person in a park shall:



      (1)   Damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or
plant or injure the bark, or pick the flowers or seeds of any tree or plant;
attach any rope, wire or other contrivance to any tree or plant; or tie or
hitch an animal to any tree or plant; or



      (2)   Climb, stand or sit upon monuments, vases, fountains,
railings, fences, trees or upon any other property not designated or
customarily used for those purposes.



   (C)   Wild animals, birds.  No person in a park shall:



      (1)   Hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap, chase, tease,
shoot or throw missiles at any animal, reptile or bird; remove or possess the
young of any wild animal, or the eggs, nest or young of any reptile or bird,
except that snakes known to be deadly poisonous, such as rattlesnakes,
moccasins, coral snakes or other deadly reptiles may be killed on sight; or



      (2)   Give or offer or attempt to give to any animal or bird
any tobacco, alcohol or other known noxious substances.



(Ord. passed 9-17-1991)



§ 12-73  SANITATION.



   No person in a park shall:



   (A)   Throw, discharge or otherwise place or cause to be placed in
the waters of any fountain, lake, stream or other body of water in or
adjacent to any park or any tributary stream, storm sewer or drain flowing
into those waters, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which
will or may result in the pollution of those waters; or



   (B)   Dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes,
paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage or refuse or other trash
anywhere on the park grounds; except the matter may be placed in proper
receptacles where provided. Where receptacles are not provided, all rubbish
or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for
its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere.



(Ord. passed 9-17-1991)



§ 12-74  TRAFFIC.



   No person in a park shall:



   (A)   Fail to comply with all applicable provisions of the motor
vehicle traffic laws of the state and ordinances of the city in regard to
equipment and operation of vehicles;



   (B)   Fail to obey all police officers, those persons being hereby
authorized and instructed to direct traffic whenever and wherever needed in
the parks in accordance with the provisions of this article and the
supplementary regulations as may be issued subsequently by the city;



   (C)   Fail to observe carefully all traffic signs, indicating speed,
direction, caution, stopping or parking, and all others posted for proper
control and to safeguard life and property;



   (D)   Ride or drive a vehicle at a rate of speed exceeding 15 mph;



   (E)   Drive any vehicle on any area except the paved park roads or
parking areas, or other areas as may on occasion be specifically designated
as temporary parking areas by the city;



   (F)   Park a vehicle in other than an established or designated
parking area. Parking shall be in accordance with the posted directions and
with the instructions of any police officer who may be present;



   (G)   Fail to immediately notify the Police Department of an
emergency in the nature of a breakdown requiring the assistance of a tow
truck, mechanic or other persons; it shall be unlawful to work on or repair
vehicles for any reasons other than emergency purposes. Under no
circumstances may a broken- down vehicle remain in a park area longer than 48
hours. The city shall be allowed to remove any vehicle at that time by having
the vehicle towed to a bonded storage facility;



   (H)   Operate any go-cart or minibike at any location within any
park other than those places, if any, as are specifically designated for that
purpose by the Department, except that regularly licensed vehicles and
operators may have access to streets and roadways within parks to the same
extent as public streets, subject to the traffic rules of this article;



   (I)   Ride a bicycle on other than the righthand side of a paved
vehicular road or path designated for that purpose; or fail to keep in single
file when two or more bicycles are operating as a group. A bicyclist shall be
permitted to wheel or push a bicycle by hand over any grassy area or wooded
trail or on any paved area reserved for pedestrian use;



   (J)   Ride any other person over the age of six years on a
single-passenger bicycle in any park;



   (K)   Leave a bicycle unattended in a place other than a bicycle
rack when one is provided and there is space available;



   (L)   Leave a bicycle lying on the ground or paving, or set against
trees or in any place or position where other persons may trip over or be
injured by it; or



   (M)   Ride a bicycle on any road between 30 minutes after sunset and
30 minutes before sunrise without an attached headlight plainly visible at
least 200 feet from the front, and without a red taillight or red reflector
plainly visible from at least 100 feet from the rear of the bicycle.



(Ord. passed 9-17-1991)



§ 12-75  RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES.



   (A)   Bathing and swimming.  No person in a park shall:



      (1)   Swim, bathe or wade in any waters on waterways in or
adjacent to any park; or



      (2)   Dress or undress in any vehicle, toilet or other place,
except in those structures as may be provided for that purpose.



   (B)   Fishing.  No person in a park shall fish by the use of a
hook, line, net, trap or other device from the spillway to the senior
citizens center, or any area that is developed or landscaped.



   (C)   Open picnic areas and use.  No person in a park shall:



      (1)   Picnic or lunch in a place other than normal picnic
areas within the parks. Visitors shall comply with any directions given to
achieve this end by the city; or



      (2)   Violate the regulations that the use of the individual
picnic area and shelters, together with tables and benches follows generally
the rule of “first come, first served;” provided, that the city may
designate certain unenclosed picnic areas as reservable, in which case the
provisions of subsection (D) below shall apply to those areas.



   (D)   Other activities.  No person in a park shall:



      (1)   Take part in or abet the playing of any games or
activities involving thrown or otherwise propelled, injurious objects such as
balls, stones, arrows, javelins or model airplanes, except in areas set apart
for those forms of recreation. The playing of rough or comparatively
dangerous games such as football, baseball and golf is prohibited except on
the fields and courts or areas provided therefor. Roller skating and
skateboarding shall be confined to those areas specifically designated for
that pastime; or



      (2)   Ride a horse except on designated bridle trails; horses
shall be thoroughly broken and properly restrained, ridden with due care, and
shall not be allowed to graze or go unattended.



(Ord. passed 9-17-1991)



§ 12-76  BEHAVIOR.



   No person in a park shall:



   (A)   Consume any malt beverage or unfortified wine, as defined in
G.S. Chapter 18B;



   (B)   Possess or consume any fortified wine or spirituous liquor, as
defined in G.S. Chapter 18B;



   (C)   Possess, use or consume any illegal drugs; or be under the
influence of any illegal drugs while in the park;



   (D)   Build or attempt to build a fire in any park, or throw or
otherwise scatter lighted matches, burning cigarettes or cigars, tobacco
paper or other flammable material, within any park area;



   (E)   Enter an area posted as “closed to the public,” nor shall
any person use or abet the use of any area in violation of posted notices;



   (F)   Lie or sleep in a prone position on seats, tables or benches;
or



   (G)   Disturb or interfere with the activities of any other person
occupying an area of a park with the intent to disrupt the activities of the
other person.



(Ord. passed 9-17-1991)



§ 12-77  MERCHANDISING, ADVERTISING AND SIGNS.



   No person in a park shall:



   (A)   Expose, offer for sale or advertise any article or service
except regularly licensed concessionaires acting by and under the authority
and regulation of the city, and/or unless a permit for the same has been
issued by the city; or



   (B)   Paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard,
advertisement or inscription whatsoever, except as authorized by the
Recreation Director.



(Ord. passed 9-17-1991)



§ 12-78  PARK OPERATING POLICY.



   (A)   Except for unusual and unforseen emergencies as determined by
the city, parks shall be open to the public every day of the year during
designated hours. The opening and closing hours for each individual park
shall be determined by the city and shall be posted therein for public
information. The City Lake Park shall be closed from 10:00 p.m. until 7:00
a.m. daily.



   (B)   Any section or part of any park may be declared closed to the
public by the city at any time and for any interval of time, either
temporarily or at regular and stated intervals (daily or otherwise) and
either entirely or merely to certain uses, as the city shall find reasonably
necessary.



   (C)   A permit shall be obtained from the city before participating
in any park activity which the city shall from time to time designate as
requiring a permit.



   (D)   Any park activity which conforms to any activity as set out in
Chapter 15 (parades, picketing and demonstrations), shall comply with the
permitting requirements of that chapter prior to engaging in that park
activity.



(Ord. passed 9-17-1991; Ord. 93-007, passed 5-11-1993)



§ 12-79  ENFORCEMENT.



   When there is a violation of any provision of this article, the city,
in its discretion, may take one or more of the following courses of action:



   (A)   The violator may be charged pursuant to G.S. §§ 14-4(a) and
(b) and be penalized as provided by the statute and its further amendments;
and/or



   (B)   The city may apply to the appropriate court for an injunction
or any other allowable civil penalty.



(Ord. passed 9-17-1991)



CHAPTER 13:  NOISE



Section



   13-1   Creation of unnecessary noise



   13-2   Unlawful noises enumerated



Cross-reference:



   Animals, see ch. 4



   Cemeteries, see ch. 6



   Motor vehicles and traffic, see ch. 11



   Parades, picketing and demonstrations, see ch. 15



Statutory reference:



   Municipal noise regulation, see G.S. § 160A-184



§ 13-1  CREATION OF UNNECESSARY NOISE.



   Subject to the provisions of this chapter, the creation of any
unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noise is prohibited. Noise of
this character, intensity and duration as to be detrimental to the life or
health of any individual is prohibited.



(1972 Code, § 14-1)



§ 13-2  UNLAWFUL NOISES ENUMERATED.



   The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing
and unnecessary noises in violation of this chapter, but this enumeration
shall not be deemed to be exclusive:



   (A)   The sounding of any horn or signal device on any automobile,
motorcycle, bus or other vehicle, except as a reasonable warning; the
creation by means of any signal device of any unreasonably loud or harsh
sound and the sounding of that device for an unnecessary and unreasonable
period of time;



   (B)   The use of any gong or siren upon any vehicle other than
police, fire or other emergency vehicle;



   (C)   The playing of any radio, phonograph or other musical
instrument in a manner or with such volume as to annoy or disturb the quiet,
comfort or repose of any person in any dwelling, hotel or other type of
residence;



   (D)   The keeping of any animal or bird which, by causing frequent
or long continued noise, disturbs the comfort and repose of any person in the
vicinity;



   (E)   The use of any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle so out
of repair, so loaded or in a manner as to create loud or unnecessary grating,
grinding, rattling or other noise;



   (F)   The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary
boiler except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a
warning of danger;



   (G)   The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam
engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor vehicle or motorboat
engine, except through a muffler or other device which will effectively
prevent loud or explosive noise therefrom;



   (H)   The use of any mechanical device operated by compressed air
unless the noise created thereby is effectively muffled and reduced;



   (I)   The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to
any school, institution of learning or court while the same is in session or
within 150 feet of any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the
working of that institution; provided, that conspicuous signs are displayed
in the street indicating that the same is a school, court or hospital street;



   (J)   The creation of any excessive noise on Sundays on any street
adjacent to any church; provided, that conspicuous signs are displayed in
those streets adjacent to churches indicating that the same is a church
street;



   (K)   The sounding of any bell or gong attached to any building or
premises which disturbs the quiet or repose of persons in the vicinity
thereof;



   (L)   The shouting and crying of peddlers, barkers, hawkers and
vendors which disturb the quiet and peace of the neighborhood;



   (M)   The use of any drum, loudspeaker, megaphone, bell, horn or
other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention, by
creation of noise, to any performance, show or other event or the sale or
display of merchandise, or the crying out of same, unless permitted by the
Council;



   (N)   The use of any mechanical loudspeakers or amplifiers on trucks
or other moving vehicles for advertising or other purposes except where
specific license is received from the Council;



   (O)   The conducting, operating or maintaining of any garage or
filling station in any residential district so as to cause loud or offensive
noises to be emitted therefrom between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.;



   (P)   The firing of gunpowder or other combustible substance in the
streets or elsewhere for the purpose of making a noise or disturbance, except
by permission from the Police Department; or



   (Q)   Shouting or screaming in a loud, boisterous manner by any
person so as to disturb the public.



   (R)   The operation of compression release engine brakes is
regulated pursuant to § 11-78.



(1972 Code, §§ 14-2, 15-22)  (Ord. 2017-08, passed 11-14-2017)



Statutory reference:



   Horns and warning devices on motor vehicles, see G.S. §
20-125–Miscellaneous



CHAPTER 14:  OFFENSES–MISCELLANEOUS



Section



   14-1   Advertising; posting signs on public poles; billboards



   14-2   Advertising; posting on property of others



   14-3   Advertising; painting on street, sidewalk



   14-4   Begging, indirect solicitation of alms



   14-5   Distribution of medicine samples



   14-6   Disturbing school decorum



   14-7   Expectoration



   14-8   Use of firearms



   14-9   Injuring, interfering with city property



   14-10   Loitering



   14-11   Playing games in streets



   14-12   Shooting projectiles; archery ranges



   14-13   Stagnant water on premises



   14-14   Disposition of decayed or perishable products



   14-15   False police or fire reports



   14-16   Accumulation of rubbish



   14-17   Smoking in municipal buildings, city-owned parks and
recreational facilities and municipal vehicles; prohibited



   14-18   Limitations on the open and concealed carrying of firearms
on certain municipal property



Statutory reference:



   Criminal law, see G.S. Chapter 14



   General ordinance-making power, see G.S. § 160A-174



§ 14-1  ADVERTISING; POSTING SIGNS ON PUBLIC POLES; BILLBOARDS.



   No person shall tack, nail or otherwise attach any sign or poster to
any tree, telephone pole or electric pole nor shall erect and maintain any
billboards.



(1972 Code, § 15-2)



Cross-reference:



   Licenses and business regulations, see ch. 10



Statutory reference:



   Unlawful posting of advertisements, see G.S. § 14-145



§ 14-2  ADVERTISING; POSTING ON PROPERTY OF OTHERS.



   No person shall post any bills, signs or advertisements on any
buildings, fences or other property belonging to another without the consent
of the owner thereof. The consent shall be secured in writing, and this
written consent shall be exhibited by the person having the same to any
police officer on demand.



(1972 Code, § 15-3)



§ 14-3  ADVERTISING; PAINTING ON STREET, SIDEWALK.



   No person shall advertise or attempt to advertise by marking or
painting on or attaching any advertisements to any street or sidewalk.



(1972 Code, § 15-4)



§ 14-4  BEGGING, INDIRECT SOLICITATION OF ALMS.



   No person shall sell or offer for sale any pencils, shoestrings,
chewing gum or similar objects in the streets or other public places as an
indirect method of soliciting alms; nor shall any person offer a cup or other
receptacle for the deposit of money or take up any collection in connection
with the playing of any musical instrument in or on the streets or other
public places.



(1972 Code, § 15-5)



Statutory reference:



   Municipal regulation of begging, see G.S. § 160A-179



§ 14-5  DISTRIBUTION OF MEDICINE SAMPLES.



   No person shall leave any sample of medicine of any kind at the
dwelling house or in the yard of any person, unless the same be left with or
in care of some person of sufficient age and discretion to care properly for
the same.



(1972 Code, § 15-9)



§ 14-6  DISTURBING SCHOOL DECORUM.



   No person shall engage by conversation, sign or otherwise the attention
of any pupil to the disturbance of the discipline of any school.



(1972 Code, § 15-10)



§ 14-7  EXPECTORATION.



   No person shall expectorate in or upon any building or premises except
in receptacles provided for that purpose.



(1972 Code, § 15-12)



§ 14-8  USE OF FIREARMS.



   (A)   No person shall fire any pistol, gun or other firearm for
sport or amusement except under the supervision of the Chief of Police.



   (B)   Subsection (A) above shall not apply to authorized firearms
training for the police or other persons, nor to uses of firearms
specifically authorized by the Council or by law.



(1972 Code, § 15-13)



Statutory reference:



   Municipal regulation of firearms, see G.S. § 160A-189



§ 14-9  INJURING, INTERFERING WITH CITY PROPERTY.



   No person shall willfully or negligently injure or interfere with any
city property.



(1972 Code, § 15-14)



Statutory reference:



   Injuring personal property, see G.S. § 14-160



   Injuring wires, fixtures and the like, of telephone, telegraph and
electric-power companies, see G.S. §§ 14-154, 14-156



   Injury to houses, churches, fences and walls, see G.S. § 14-144



   Injury to public buildings and facilities, see G.S. § 14-132



   Willful and wanton injury to real property, see G.S. § 14-127



§ 14-10  LOITERING.



   No person shall habitually loaf or loiter on the streets, nor shall any
persons congregate on the streets or sidewalks or other area open to the
public in a way as to obstruct or interfere with the free passage into or out
of any public business or private property.



(1972 Code, § 15-17)



§ 14-11  PLAYING GAMES IN STREETS.



   No person shall play baseball, football or other games of similar
nature on any public street.



(1972 Code, § 15-19)



Cross-reference:



   Streets and sidewalks, see ch. 18



§ 14-12  SHOOTING PROJECTILES; ARCHERY RANGES.



   No person shall shoot or project any stone, rock, shot or other hard
substance by means of a slingshot, bean shooter, shot shooter, air rifle,
popgun, bow or other similar contrivance; provided, that archery shooting may
be engaged in on those grounds as may be set aside and approved therefor by
the City Manager or his or her designated agent.



(1972 Code, § 15-21)



§ 14-13  STAGNANT WATER ON PREMISES.



   No stagnant water shall be allowed to remain in any pool, pond, sink or
open vessel on any lot or premises or in the cellar of any building within
the city limits. Any person owning or controlling property where there is a
pond, sink or stagnant water of any kind shall fill or drain the same within
ten days after notice to do so is served upon him or her by the city
authorities.



(1972 Code, § 11-1)



Cross-reference:



   Water and sewers, see ch. 21



§ 14-14  DISPOSITION OF DECAYED OR PERISHABLE PRODUCTS.



   (A)   No person shall burn within the fire limits any decayed meats
or perishable products or other matter or material which would be likely,
when burning, to create an offensive odor.



   (B)   Persons handling or keeping meats or perishable products for
sale or otherwise shall provide themselves with a sanitary receptacle in
which all decayed meats or perishables shall be deposited.



   (C)   The receptacle shall be kept closed tightly at all times
except when it is being filled or emptied, and the accumulated contents shall
be disposed of by the city.



(1972 Code, § 11-3)



§ 14-15  FALSE POLICE OR FIRE REPORTS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to give, or cause to be given, in
any manner, a false police report or a false fire report.



(1972 Code, §§ 9-15, 15-14)



Cross-reference:



   Fire prevention and protection, see ch. 9



Statutory reference:



   False fire alarm, see G.S. § 14-286



§ 14-16  ACCUMULATION OF RUBBISH.



   No person shall permit the accumulation of waste paper, weeds, litter
or rubbish of any kind on roofs or other places where that material may
present a fire hazard.



(1972 Code, § 9-5)



Cross-reference:



   Fire prevention and protection, see ch. 9



   Solid waste and vegetation, see ch. 17



§ 14-17  SMOKING IN MUNICIPAL BUILDINGS, CITY-OWNED PARKS AND RECREATIONAL
FACILITIES AND MUNICIPAL VEHICLES; PROHIBITED.



   (A)   Definitions.  For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.



      CITY PARK AND RECREATIONAL FACILITIES.  Any park area that is
owned, leased as lessor or leased as lessee and occupied by the city.



      SMOKING or SMOKING.  The inhaling, exhaling, burning of a
tobacco product, weed, filler or plant of any kind directly as in the form of
a cigar, or in a cigarette, or a pipe, or in any other device or includes the
carrying of a lighted cigarette, cigar, pipe or any other lighted smoking
equipment.



      TOBACCO PRODUCTS.  Any product that contains tobacco and is
intended for human consumption.



   (B)   Use of tobacco products in regulated in municipal buildings. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any tobacco products in any
building or portion of a building now or hereafter owned, leased, operated,
occupied, managed or controlled by the city.



   (C)   Use of tobacco products in regulated in municipal vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any tobacco products in any
vehicle now or hereafter owned, leased, operated, occupied, managed or
controlled by the city.



   (D)   Smoking in city-owned park and recreational facilities.  The
use of any tobacco products are prohibited in the city-owned park and
recreational facilities.



   (E)   Conflict of laws.  If any portion of this section or the
enforcement thereof is found to be preempted by state or federal law, the
preemption shall not operate to invalidate the rest of the section and the
same shall remain in full force and effect. All ordinances or parts of
ordinances in conflict with this section are hereby repealed.



   (F)   Violations.  Per G.S. § 130A-498(c1), continuing to smoke in
violation of a local ordinance or other rules, laws or policies adopted under
this section constitutes an infraction, and the person committing the
infraction may be punished by a fine of not more than $50. Conviction of an
infraction under this section has no consequence other than payment of a
penalty. A person smoking in violation of a local ordinance or other rules,
laws or policies adopted under this section may not be assessed court costs.



(Ord. 93-010, passed 8-10-1993; Ord. 03-2006, passed 6-13-2006; Ord. 07-2011,
passed 11-1-2011)



Statutory reference:



   Authority to protect the health, safety and welfare of municipal
employees, see G.S. § 160A-174



§ 14-18  LIMITATIONS ON THE OPEN AND CONCEALED CARRYING OF FIREARMS ON
CERTAIN MUNICIPAL PROPERTY.



   (A)   Concealed handguns.



      (1)   The carrying of concealed handguns by all persons,
including persons with a concealed handgun permit, is prohibited in all city
buildings; within the appurtenant premises of city buildings; and all
city-owned, leased or otherwise occupied recreational facilities. For the
limited purposes of this division (A) only, the term RECREATIONAL FACILITIES,
as defined by G.S. § 14-415.23, includes only the following:



         (a)   Athletic fields, including any appurtenant
facilities such as restrooms, during an organized athletic event if the field
had been scheduled for use with the City Parks and Recreation Department;



         (b)   Swimming pools, including any appurtenant
facilities used for dressing, storage of personal items, or other uses
relating to the swimming pools; and



         (c)   A facility used for athletic events, including,
but not limited to, a gymnasium.



      (2)   For the limited purposes of this division (A) only, the
term RECREATIONAL FACILITIES does not include any greenway, designated biking
or walking path, an area that is customarily used as a walkway or bike path
although not specifically designated for such use, or open areas or fields
where athletic events may occur unless the area qualifies as an “athletic
field” pursuant to this division. As provided by the G.S. § 14-415.23, a
concealed handgun permittee may secure the handgun in a locked vehicle within
the trunk, glove box, or other enclosed compartment or area within or on the
motor vehicle.



   (B)   Openly carried firearms. The open carrying of firearms of any
kind is prohibited in all city buildings; on the grounds and parking areas of
all city buildings; and in all city-owned, leased or otherwise occupied parks
and recreational facilities. As provided in G.S. § 14-409.40, a person may
store a firearm within a motor vehicle while the vehicle is on city
premises. 



   (C)   Law enforcement personnel. The restrictions set forth in
divisions (A) and (B) do not apply to law enforcement personnel acting within
the scope of their duties.



   (D)   Posting of signs required. The City Manager or his or her
designated official is hereby authorized and instructed to post conspicuous
signage at appropriate locations on or within each park, recreational
facility and building or portion of a building owned, leased as lessee,
operated, occupied, managed or controlled by the city, as well as the
appurtenant premises to those buildings, indicating that carrying a concealed
handgun and the open carry of all firearms are prohibited or restricted as
provided by this section.



   (E)   Location of signs. Signs shall be visibly posted on the
exterior of each entrance by which the general public can access the
building. The City Manager or his or her designated official shall exercise
discretion in determining the number and appropriate location of signs to be
placed on or within appurtenant premises, parks and recreational facilities.



   (F)   Authority; severability; conflict of laws. This section is
adopted pursuant to authority granted by G.S. §§ 14-409.40 and 14-415.23.
If this section or application thereof to any person or circumstance is held
invalid, the invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of
the section which can be given separate effect and to that end the provisions
of this section are declared to be several.



(Ord. passed 10-10-1995; Ord. 2016-03, passed 3-8-2016)



CHAPTER 15:  PARADES, PICKETING AND DEMONSTRATIONS



Section



   15-1   Definitions



   15-2   Permit; required



   15-3   Permit; conditions for issuance



   15-4   Permit; revocation



   15-5   Certain activities prohibited



   15-6   Interference with parades, demonstrations prohibited



   15-7   Limitations on picketing



   15-8   Exceptions



Cross-reference:



   Animals, see ch. 4



   Emergencies, see ch. 7



   Motor vehicles and traffic, see ch. 11



   Municipal lakes, parks and recreation, see ch. 12



   Noise, see ch. 13



   Streets and sidewalks, see ch. 18



Statutory reference:



   Local regulation of processions and assemblages, see G.S. § 20-169



   Picketing or parading near court building, see G.S. § 14-225.1



   Weapons at parades and the like, see G.S. § 14-277.2



§ 15-1  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section.



   BLOCK.  The portion of any street lying between its intersections with
other streets.



   GROUP DEMONSTRATION.  Any assembly in the street or concert of action
between or among two or more persons for the purpose of protesting any matter
or of making known any position or promotion of those persons or of or on
behalf of any organization or class of persons or for the purpose of
attracting attention to the assembly.



   PARADE.  Any assemblage of two or more persons participating in or
operating any vehicle in any march, ceremony, show, exhibition or procession
of any kind in or upon the public streets or other public places.



   PICKET LINE.  Any two or more persons formed for the purpose of making
known any position or promotion of those persons or of or on behalf of any
organization or class of persons.



(Ord. passed 8-9-1988)



Cross-reference:



   Definitions and rules of construction generally, see § 1-2



§ 15-2  PERMIT; REQUIRED.



   No person shall organize, conduct or participate in any parade or group
demonstration in or upon any street, within the city, unless a permit
therefor has been issued by the city in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter.



(Ord. passed 8-9-1988)



§ 15-3  PERMIT; CONDITIONS FOR ISSUANCE.



   The Chief of Police or his or her designee is authorized to issue
permits as required in § 15-2, and in the issuance thereof shall:



   (A)   Require a written application for a permit to be filed up to
72 hours in advance of the parade or group demonstration;



   (B)   Require that the application for a permit specify whether or
not minors below the age of 18 years will be permitted to participate; and



   (C)   Require that the application for a permit shall specify and
the permit shall designate the person in charge of the activity. That person
shall be required to accompany the parade or group demonstration and shall
carry the permit with him or her at that time. The permit shall not be valid
in the possession of any other person.



(Ord. passed 8-9-1988)



§ 15-4  PERMIT; REVOCATION.



   The Chief of Police shall revoke any permit granted for a parade or
group demonstration for any of the following causes:



   (A)   The violation by any participant of § 15-5; or



   (B)   The failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the
permit.



(Ord. passed 8-9-1988)



§ 15-5  CERTAIN ACTIVITIES PROHIBITED.



   The following acts or activities, when performed or undertaken in
conjunction with or as a part of any parade or group demonstration are hereby
prohibited and declared unlawful:



   (A)   The carrying on or about the person any firearm or any weapon
or article, including, but not limited to, blackjacks, nightsticks or
flashlights which by their use might constitute a deadly weapon; and



   (B)   The taking or keeping of any dog or any vicious animal,
whether leashed or unleashed.



(Ord. passed 8-9-1988)



§ 15-6  INTERFERENCE WITH PARADES, DEMONSTRATIONS PROHIBITED.



   No person shall hamper, obstruct or interfere with any parade or group
demonstration being conducted under authority of a permit duly issued by the
Chief of Police.



(Ord. passed 8-9-1988)



§ 15-7  LIMITATIONS ON PICKETING.



   Picket lines and picketing shall be subject to the following
regulations.



   (A)   Picketing may be conducted only on the sidewalks reserved for
pedestrian movement and may not be conducted on the portion of a street used
primarily for vehicular traffic.



   (B)   Not more than ten pickets promoting the same objective shall
be permitted to use either of the two sidewalks within a single block at any
one time.



   (C)   Pickets may carry written or printed placards or signs not
exceeding two feet in width and two feet in length promoting the objective
for which the picketing is done, provided that the words used are not
derogatory or defamatory in nature.



   (D)   Pickets must march in single file and not abreast and not
march closer together than 15 feet, except in passing one another.



   (E)   If pickets promoting different objectives desire to use the
same sidewalk for picketing and the use would result in the presence of more
than ten pickets thereon, the Chief of Police shall allot time to each group
of pickets for the use of the sidewalk on an equitable basis. Each group
shall be allowed the use, subject to the provisions of this section, at least
once every two hours.



   (F)   Pickets shall not block intersections or driveways.



   (G)   Pickets shall not carry on or about the person any firearm or
any weapon or article including, but not limited to, blackjacks, nightsticks
or flashlights which by their use might constitute a deadly weapon.



   (H)   No picket shall have any dog or any vicious animal, whether
leashed or unleashed.



   (I)   It shall be unlawful for any person to hamper, obstruct or
interfere with any pickets except police officers may stop any picketing
activity if it becomes unlawful.



(Ord. passed 8-9-1988)



§ 15-8  EXCEPTIONS.



   The provision of this chapter shall not apply to:



   (A)   Funeral processions; and



   (B)   Any governmental agency acting within the scope of its
functions.



(Ord. passed 8-9-1988)

ARTICLE I:  IN GENERAL



§ 17-1  LITTERING.



   (A)   No person shall throw or deposit in any manner trash, garbage,
litter, refuse, waste or any other substance upon any street, sidewalk, alley
or public way in the city, or upon any property owned by the city, whether by
throwing same from a motor vehicle or in any other manner. This section shall
not prohibit the orderly placement of trash on the street or curb for
collection by the city.



   (B)   Subsection (A) above shall not apply to regular employees of
the city working under orders and directions of the City Manager and Council
and to persons acting pursuant to permits from the city.



(1972 Code, §§ 10-1, 15-16.1)



§ 17-2  SWEEPINGS; PROTECTION OF CATCHBASINS.



   No person shall sweep into any street, sidewalk or gutter, nor shall
throw into any catchbasin, any substance or object.



(1972 Code, § 10-4)



§ 17-3  DUMPING PROHIBITED.



   No garbage or offensive or disease-producing materials shall be dumped
for any purpose on any lot or space within the city limits.



(1972 Code, § 10-11)



§ 17-4  HAULING REFUSE INTO CITY.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to haul or carry any garbage,
refuse or debris into the city from outside the city and leave or deposit
garbage, refuse or debris within the city.



(Ord. passed 6-14-1988)



ARTICLE II:  GARBAGE AND REFUSE GENERALLY



§ 17-31  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section.



   ASHES.  The refuse from fires in houses, schools, stores and the like,
and includes at times small quantities of glass, crockery, sweepings, dust,
brick, metal and other inorganic materials.



   GARBAGE.  The organic waste matter, both animal and vegetable, from
houses, kitchens, restaurants, hotels, hospitals and the like, comprised
chiefly of waste food and does not include liquids that may be drained into
the sewer.



   REFUSE.  Includes tin cans, dirty rags, old clothes, waste and other
materials not otherwise designated herein.



(1972 Code, § 10-2)



Cross-reference:



   Definitions and rules of construction generally, see § 1-2



§ 17-32  PLACEMENT OF TREE LIMBS, TRIMMINGS, OTHER DEBRIS FOR COLLECTION.



   (A)   All tree limbs and trunks shall be cut into pieces not
exceeding six feet in length and placed neatly in a pile. No individual piece
shall exceed 50 pounds in weight. All trimmings, shrubbery and the like shall
be cut into pieces not exceeding six feet in length.



   (B)   All debris placed for removal by the city shall be placed
within the parkway strip between the curb and the sidewalk at the front of
the premises; provided, however, that if there is no sidewalk and curb, the
debris shall be placed at the front of the premises reasonably adjacent to
the street. No debris shall be placed in any street, gutter, canal, ditch or
drainageway or upon any sidewalk in the city.



(Ord. passed 6-14-1988; Ord. passed 7-12-1988)



§ 17-32.5  RESPONSIBILITY FOR REMOVAL OF APPLIANCES; DEBRIS.



   (A)   For the purpose of this section, APPLIANCES shall be deemed to
be discarded water heaters, refrigerators, freezers, stoves, washers, dryers,
televisions and window mounted air conditioning units.



   (B)   All persons having control of any lot or any part thereof in
the city shall be entitled to curbside pickup and disposal by the city of
discarded appliances subject to those requirements as may be set by the City
Manager.



   (C)   Any building debris or other debris as set out in § 17-61,
which cannot be placed in two trash cans as required for weekly pickup of
garbage by the city shall be removed from each lot by the lot owner or person
having control of a lot or any part thereof.



   (D)   Any violation of this section shall be enforced in the same
manner that § 17-61 is enforced.



(Ord. passed 6-12-1990)



§ 17-33 INTERFERENCE WITH RECEPTACLES, COLLECTION PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT;
PERMIT OR FRANCHISE REQUIREMENT.



   (A)   No person shall molest or interfere with the contents of any
receptacles set out for removal by the City Public Works Department.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere in any manner
with yard waste collectors or yard waste collection and transportation
equipment.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business
of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of yard waste placed on
city rights-of-way within the corporate limits of the city without a permit
or franchise from the city.



   (D)   Subsections (B) and (C) above will not prohibit someone from
getting permission from a property owner to rake up pine straw from their
property for resale. This only prohibits noncity personnel from collecting
pine straw and other yard waste from the city rights-of-way.



(1972 Code, § 10-5)  (Ord. passed 9-9-1986)



§ 17-34  PLACEMENT OF RECEPTACLES FOR COLLECTION.



   Each landlord, tenant or storekeeper shall see that the various garbage
and refuse receptacles and their contents, as herein provided for, are set
out for the convenience of the collector in or immediately adjacent to the
nearest alley or curb or at another place and at a time as may be fixed by
the Public Works Department.



(1972 Code, § 10-6)



§ 17-35  RECEPTACLES TO BE REMOVED AFTER COLLECTION.



   Each landlord, tenant or storekeeper shall restore the garbage and
refuse receptacles to their proper place within 12 hours after collection of
the contents by the Public Works Department.



(1972 Code, § 10-7)



§ 17-36  INSPECTION OF RECEPTACLES.



   All garbage receptacles shall be inspected as to their sanitary
condition ,and if and when found in an unsanitary condition, the Department
of Public Works shall furnish the owner of the receptacle a notice to correct
the condition as to container and its unsanitary condition if such should
prevail. If the owner does not correct this condition in a reasonable length
of time, the Director of Public Works shall take the necessary steps to have
the owners to comply with state and city sanitary requirements.



(1972 Code, § 10-8)



§ 17-37  CITY EMPLOYEES SHALL NOT DISCHARGE DUTIES OF TENANTS, STOREKEEPERS
AND THE LIKE.



   No employee of the city shall assist in any way in the performance of
what has been set forth as the duty of the landlord, tenant or storekeeper
with the reference to the enforcement of this article.



(1972 Code, § 10-9)



§ 17-38  COLLECTORS TO USE REASONABLE CARE.



   Collectors shall exercise reasonable care in the handling of garbage
receptacles and shall not willfully break, deface or injure the same.



(1972 Code, § 10-10)



§ 17-39  STABLE AND KENNEL MANURE.



   Stable or kennel manure shall be removed by persons who maintain
stables or kennels and not by city employees.



(1972 Code, § 10-12)



Cross-reference:



   Animals, see ch. 4



§ 17-40  STICKER PROGRAM GUIDELINES.



   (A)   Stickers are sold to remove white goods and bulky curbside
trash items and must be purchased at the Public Works Department, located at
1000 Oakhurst Avenue, Hamlet, North Carolina, (910-582-7987).



   (B)   At time of sticker purchase, you will be scheduled for a
pick-up date.



   (C)   Stickers must be applied to the front of the item as
registered with the Public Works office for pick up to take place. (No
substitute to be made).



   (D)   Stickered items must be placed curbside by 6:00 a.m. the day
of pickup or no earlier than 6:00 p.m. the night before.



   (E)   The pickups may begin promptly at 6:00 a.m.



   (F)   If you are unable to have the items out as scheduled, it is
your responsibility to notify the Public Works office (910-582-7987) no later
than 12:00 noon on the day before the scheduled pickup date. At the time of
the call, we will schedule you for an optional date or stickers may be put on
hold for future use.



   (G)   If the city is unsuccessful at picking up the items on the
scheduled date, then you will need to contact the Public Works office
(910-582-7987) to purchase additional stickers and schedule a later pickup
date. Again, it is very important that you call us no later than 12:00 noon
on the day before the scheduled pickup date to avoid any further charges for
rescheduling. Items cannot remain at the curb until another date.



   (H)   There are no refunds on this program. Monies collected will be
applied as administration fees.



   (I)   Should you have any questions or concerns, please do not
hesitate to contact the Public Works office at 910-582-7987.



   (J)   Items not available for pick up include:



      (1)   Building materials;



      (2)   Paint;



      (3)   Tires; and



      (4)   Shingles.



(Ord. passed 6-14-2011)

§ 17-42  ROLL-OUT GARBAGE CARTS.



   (A)   Additional carts.  Residences and businesses will be issued
one roll-out cart at no cost to them. Residences and businesses will be
allowed to purchase up to two additional roll-out carts at cost and assessed
an additional charge per pick-up, per cart.



   (B)   Number of pickups per week.



      (1)   All residences in the city will receive one household
garbage pickup per week. The day of pickup will be determined by the garbage
route as set by the Public Works Department.



      (2)   Certain small commercial establishments will receive two
garbage pickups per week. The day of pickup will be determined by the Public
Works Department. Any commercial establishments that generate more than six
96-gallon roll-out carts of trash/garbage per week must utilize a private
dumpster service.



(Ord. passed 11-12-1996)



ARTICLE III:  NUISANCES



§ 17-61  DECLARATION; ENUMERATION.



   The existence of any of the following conditions on any vacant lot or
other parcel of land within the corporate limits, or within one mile thereof,
is hereby declared to be dangerous and prejudicial to the public health or
safety and to constitute a public nuisance:



   (A)   The uncontrolled growth of noxious weeds or grass, not grown
for agriculture purposes, to a height in excess of 12 inches on the average,
causing, or threatening to cause, a hazard detrimental to the public health
or safety. It shall also be the duty of the owner to cut and remove all weeds
and other rank vegetation as often as necessary so as to comply with this
subsection. This subsection does not apply to lots exceeding one acre in size
or lots which are covered with trees. However, lots exceeding one acre or
lots covered with trees shall be maintained in accordance with this
subsection to a depth of ten feet from the property lines, if, and only if,
the adjacent property is occupied by a dwelling or other structure located
within 50 feet of the property;



   (B)   Any accumulation, including burial, of animal or vegetable
matter that is offensive by virtue of odors or vapors or by the inhabitancy
therein of rats, mice, snakes or vermin of any kind which or may be dangerous
or prejudicial to the public health;



   (C)   Any accumulation or rubbish, trash or junk causing, or
threatening to cause, a fire hazard, the accumulation of stagnant water or
the inhabitation therein of rats, mice, snakes or vermin of any kind which is
or may be dangerous or prejudicial to the public health;



   (D)   Any ditches, drains or culverts which are not kept properly
clean from June 1 until November 1 of each year;



   (E)   Any sinkhole whereby unclean or stagnant water may stand or be
conveyed into the streets or alleys, or keeping, or permitting to be kept,
any bucket, can, barrel or any other receptacle whereby unclean or stagnant
water may accumulate or stand;



   (F)   Operating a junkyard, or dismantling secondhand automobiles
for the purpose of salvaging and selling the parts thereof, or storing
unserviceable automobiles, or parts thereof, in areas on the outside of
buildings or in open lots;



   (G)   Any condition detrimental to the public health, which violates
the rules and regulations of the County Health Inspector; and



   (H)   Any condition which results from the failure of the owner,
occupant or other person in control of any building or land in the city,
including vacant property, to keep the building or land in a clean and
orderly condition.



(Ord. passed 10-14-1986; Ord. passed 3-1-2008; Ord. passed 11-11-2008)



§ 17-62  RESERVED.



Editor’s note:



   This section was reserved by an ordinance passed March 1, 2008.



§ 17-63  INVESTIGATION.



   The City Manager, upon notice from any person of the possible existence
of any of the conditions described in § 17-61, shall cause to be made by the
appropriate County Health Department Official or city official an
investigation as may be necessary to determine whether conditions exist which
may constitute a public nuisance as declared in § 17-61.



(Ord. passed 10-14-1986)



§ 17-64  VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES; ABATEMENT BY CITY.



   (A)   Upon investigation and finding by the City Manager that any
premises is being maintained in violation of § 17-61, the City Manager or
authorized person is hereby vested with authority to give written notice,
which may be served personally, by registered mail or in any other manner
authorized by law to the owner, occupant or person in charge of those
premises or to any two or all of the persons believed to be responsible for
the violation. The notice shall specify the condition which constitutes the
violation and shall direct the addressee to abate the violation in a lawful
manner within ten days from the date of the notice. The notice shall also
warn the addressee that failure to comply with this notice shall subject him
or her to prosecution for his or her violation and, in addition, shall render
him or her liable to the city for any costs and expenses which may be
incurred by the city in the abatement of the violation under the provisions
of subsection (B) below, and that the costs and expenses shall constitute a
lien upon the property involved.



   (B)   If upon the expiration of the time specified in any notice,
the condition which constitutes the violation has not been abated in a lawful
manner, the City Manager or authorized person shall provide for the abatement
of the condition by the most expedient means, and the costs and expenses
thereby incurred, including any cost incurred in service of the notice, shall
be collected by the City Tax Collector from any one or more of the addresses
served with notice, and, if the costs and expenses are not paid within 30
days, the City Tax Collector shall make collection thereof in the manner
provided by law for delinquent taxes, or in any other manner authorized by
law; and the amount of the costs and expense shall constitute a lien in favor
of the city upon the property upon which the violation occurred.



   (C)   In addition to the sanctions imposed in subsection (B) above,
a violation of this article or any order issued under this article shall also
be a civil offense and shall subject the offender to a civil penalty as
follows.



      (1)   If the offender shall abate the nuisance within ten days
from the date of the notice and shall not within the preceding three years
have been notified of any prior violation of this article, no penalty shall
be assessed.



      (2)   If the offender shall abate the nuisance within ten days
from the date of the notice but shall within the preceding three years have
been notified of any prior violation of this article, a civil penalty in the
amount of $200 shall be assessed.



      (3)   If the offender shall not abate the nuisance within ten
days from the date of the notice, a civil penalty in the amount of $50 shall
be assessed for each day and every day during which the violation shall
continue. Each day shall be a separate and distinct violation of this section.



(Ord. passed 3-1-2008)



§ 17-65  RESERVED.



Editor’s note:



   This section was reserved by an ordinance passed March 1, 2008.



§ 17-66  RESERVED.



Editor’s note:



   This section was reserved by an ordinance passed March 1, 2008.



§ 17-67  RESERVED.



Editor’s note:



   This section was reserved by an ordinance passed March 1, 2008.



§ 17-68  DEFECTS IN SERVICE OF NOTICE.



   Defects in the method of giving the notice as specified in § 17-64 or
in the form thereof or the giving of notice to an improper person shall not
prevent the city in any case where the work of abating any violation of this
article is actually done by the city from collecting the cost thereof from
the owner of the premises upon which the violations occurred, nor shall it
affect the validity of the lien on the cost.



(Ord. passed 3-1-2008)



§ 17-69  ADDITIONAL REMEDIES.



   The procedure set forth in this article shall be in addition to any
other remedies that may now or hereafter exist under law for the abatement of
public nuisances and this article shall not prevent the city from proceeding
in a criminal action against any person violating the provisions of this
article as provided in G.S. § 14-4.



(Ord. passed 10-14-1986)



§ 17-70  OWNERS, OCCUPANTS AND THE LIKE JOINTLY LIABLE.



   The owner, lessee, tenant or occupant of any building or premises where
there is a nuisance or any violation of an ordinance or provision of this
Code relating to health and sanitation shall be jointly and severally liable
therefor, and each of them may be required to abate the same or comply with
the order of the Chief of Police or his or her assistants within the time
specified within the order.



(1972 Code, § 11-4)
